definition: A commercial name for green aniline dye.
A country seat; a country or suburban residence of somepretensions to elegance. Dryden. Cowper.
One of the States of the United States of America.-- a.
Having no veil. Tennyson.
A small worm or insect larva; also, a wormlike body. [R.]Derham.

Excessive vanity excited by one's own performances; emptypride; undue elation of mind; vain show; boastfulness.He had nothing of vainglory. Bacon.The man's undone forever; for if Hector break not his neck i' thecombat, he'll break't himself in vainglory. Shak.
The quality or state of being visionary.
One of a class of temporal officers who originally representedthe bishops, but later erected their offices into fiefs, and becamefeudal nobles.

An automatic machine gun in which the mechanism is worked bythe recoil, assisted by the pressure of gases from the muzzle, whichexpand in a gas chamber against a disk attached to the end of thebarrel, thus moving the latter to the rear with increased recoil, andagainst the front wall of the gas chamber, checking the recoil of thesystem.
A literal adherent to, or a minute critic of, words; aliteralist.
The god of fire, who presided over the working of metals; --answering to the Greek Hephæstus.
Violent. [Obs.] J. Fletcher.
Victorious. "The victor Greeks." Pope.
A local twitching, or convulsive motion, of a muscular fiber,especially of the face.
A villain. [R.]
A liquid hydrocarbon obtained by the decomposition of veratricacid, and constituting the dimethyl ether of pyrocatechin.
Electric potential or potential difference, expressed in volts.
Covered with wartlike elevations; tuberculate; warty;verrucous; as, a verrucose capsule.
A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the bla; as in vesicoprostatic, vesicovaginal.
A genus of carnivores which comprises the civets.
See Varix.
Something expressed verbally; a verbal remark or expression.
Any one of numerous species of siliceous fossil spongesbelonging to Ventriculites and allied genera, characteristic of theCretaceous period.
Bladdery; full of, or covered with, bladders; vesicular.
Lively; active; sprightly; vigorous. [Obs.]Even her body was made airy and vegete. Jer. Taylor.
Belonging or relating to volition. "The volitional impulse."Bacon.
A vessel; a duct. Vas deferens; pl. Vasa deferentia. Etym: [L.vas vessel + deferens carrying down.] (Anat.) The excretory duct of atesticle; a spermatic duct.
Given to, or characterized by, vagaries; capricious; whimsical;crochety.

An oath administered to a witness, usually before being swornin chief, requiring him to speak the truth, or make true answers inreference to matters inquired of, to ascertain his competency to giveevidence. Greenleaf. Ld. Abinger.
Inclined to vacillate; wavering; irresolute. Hawthorne.
A ketone of valeric acid obtained as an oily liquid.

One of the maidens of Odin, represented as awful and beautiful,who presided over battle and marked out those who were to be slain,and who also ministered at the feasts of heroes in Valhalla. [Writtenalso Valkyr, and Walkyr.]
A whorl of a spiral shell.
Vagabondage.
One who vituperates, or censures abusively.
A tube for drawing liquors from a cask by the bunghole.[Written also velinche.]
Of the nature of a vowel. [R.] "The power [of w] is alwaysvowelish." B. Jonson.
Villainous. [Obs.] "Vileyns sinful deeds make a churl."Chaucer.

A navy of vessels fitted out and manned by volunteers who sailunder the flag of the regular navy and subject to naval discipline.Prussia in 1870, in the Franco-German war, organized such a navy,which was commanded by merchant seamen with temporary commissions,with the claim (in which England acquiesced) that it did not comewithin the meaning of the term privateer.

The use of many words without necessity, or with little sense;a superabundance of words; verbosity; wordiness.Verbiage may indicate observation, but not thinking. W. Irving.This barren verbiage current among men. Tennyson.
To cry out with vehemence; to exclaim; to bawl; to clamor.Cowper.
A place artificially arranged for keeping or raising livinganimals, as a park, a pond, an aquarium, a warren, etc.
A small box, usually jeweled or of precious metal and worn on achain, containing a mirror, powder puff, and other small toiletarticles for a woman.

The brief terminal part of vowel or vocal element, differingmore or less in quality from the main part; as, a as in aleordinarily ends with a vanish of i as in ill, o as in old with avanish of oo as in foot. Rush.
A small yellow-headed bird (Auriparus flaviceps) of LowerCalifornia, allied to the titmice; -- called also goldtit.
An extensive tribe of bivalve mollusks of which the genus Venusis the type. The shells are usually oval, or somewhat heartshaped,with a conspicuous lunule. See Venus.
A modified form of dentine, which is permeated by bloodcapillaries; vascular dentine.
A whorl; a verticil.
Of or pertaining to a virgin; becoming a virgin; maidenly."Chastity and honor virginal." Spenser. Virginal generation (Biol.),parthenogenesis.-- Virginal membrane (Anat.), the hymen.
Familiar; conversant. [R.]Men not versant with courts of justice. Sydney Smith.
A standard bearer. Tennyson.
Vespertine. Lowell.
Destitute of vision; sightless.
An extensive artificial group of birds including the wading,swimming, and cursorial birds.
In very truth; beyond doubt or question; in fact; certainly.Bacon.Trust in the Lord and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the verily thoushalt be fed. Ps. xxxvii. 3.
Sticking or adhering, and having a ropy or glutinousconsistency; viscous; glutinous; sticky; tenacious; clammy; as,turpentine, tar, gums, etc., are more or less viscid.
The quality or state of being vacillant, or wavering. [R.] Dr.H. More.
A kind of sweet wine from Italy. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Inflammation of the vulva.
Volcanicity.
A vicar. [Obs.] Marston.
A kind of instrument for holding work, as in filing. Same asVise.

Long exercised in anything, especially in military life and theduties of a soldier; long practiced or experienced; as, a veteranofficer or soldier; veteran skill.The insinuating eloquence and delicate flattery of veterandiplomatists and courtiers. Macaulay.
Empty; unfilled; void; vacant.Boundless the deep, because I am who fill Infinitude; nor vacuous thespace. Milton.That the few may lead selfish and vacuous days. J. Morley.
Vehemence. [R.]The vehemency of your affection. Shak.
To poison; to infect with poison. [R.] Harvey.
Capable of being vended, or sold; that may be sold; salable.The regulating of prices of things vendible. Bacon.
Converted into glass.
In the Orkney and Shetland Islands, beef and mutton hung anddried, but not salted. [Scot.] [Written also vivda.] Jamieson.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C5H8; -- called also pentine.
A woman's fur tippet.
Any one of several species of parrots of the genus Coracopsis,native of Madagascar; -- called also vasa parrot.

An instrument consisting essentially of a glass tube providedwith a graduated scale, for exhibiting to the eye the changes ofvolume of a gas or gaseous mixture resulting from chemical action,and the like.
A kind of cloth, usually cotton, made in imitation of velvet;cotton velvet.
Capable of being violated, broken, or injured.-- Vi"o*la*bly, adv.
In a vehement manner.
The act of emptying; evacuation. [R.]
Of or pertaining to a ventriloquist or ventriloquism.
To twitch; to cause to twitch convulsively.Convulsions, arising from something vellicating a nerve in itsextremity, are not very dangerous. Arbuthnot.
The act or process of making vernacular, or the state of beingmade vernacular. Fitzed. Hall.
Near; neighboring; vicinal. [R.] Glanvill.
Consecrated by a vow or promise; consequent on a vow; devoted;promised.Votary resolution is made equipollent to custom. Bacon.
One who holds the doctrine that the space between the bodies ofthe universe, or the molecules and atoms of matter., is a vacuum; --opposed to plenist.
The fine shag or nap of velvet; a piece of velvet; velvetgoods.
A performer on some instrument, as the violin or the piano, whoexcels in the technical part of his art; a brilliant concert player.
Given to wine; drunken; intemperate. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An arched structure of masonry, forming a ceiling or canopy.The long-drawn aisle and fretted vault. Gray.
The quality of being viviparous; viviparity.

Pertaining to, or derived from, plants of the genus Veratrum.Veratric acid (Chem.), an acid occurring, together with veratrine, inthe root of white hellebore (Veratrum album), and in sabadilla seed;-- extracted as a white crystalline substance which is related toprotocatechuic acid.

Of or pertaining to victory, or a victor' being a victor;bringing or causing a victory; conquering; winning; triumphant; as, avictorious general; victorious troops; a victorious day.But I shall rise victorious, and subdue My vanquisher. Milton.Now are our brows bound wind victorious wreaths. Shak.-- Vic*to"ri*ous*ly, adv.-- Vic*to"ri*ous*ness, n.
Change of termination of words, as in declension, conjugation,derivation, etc.
The wife of a viscount.

To change the properties of, as caoutchouc, or India rubber, bythe process of vulcanization. Vulcanized fiber, paper, paper pulp, orother fiber, chemically treated, as with metallic chlorides, so as toform a substance resembling ebonite in texture, hardness, etc.Knight.-- Vulcanized rubber, India rubber, vulcanized.
The whidah bird.
A whorl of flowers apparently of one cluster, but composed oftwo opposite axillary cymes, as in mint. See Illust. of Whorl.
One who villanizes. [R.]
Any one of numerous species of handsomely colored butterfliesbelonging to Vanessa and allied genera. Many of these species havethe edges of the wings irregularly scalloped.
A disease in sheep, in which they pine away. [Written alsovinquish.]
In a vagrant manner.
An exuberant morbid outgrowth upon any part, especially uponthe valves of the heart. Vegetation of salts (Old Chem.), acrystalline growth of an arborescent form.
A vicar. [Obs.]
The rabble; the crowd; the mob.Shall they hoist me up, And show me to the shouting varletry Ofcensuring Rome. Shak.
A short or weak utterance; a faint or feeble sound, as thatheard on separating the lips in pronouncing p or b. Rush.-- Voc"u*lar, a.
A kind of glass which is very hard and difficult to fuse, usedas an insulator in electrical lamps and other apparatus.
Prediction; prophecy.It is not a false utterance; it is a true, though an impetuous,vaticination. I. Taylor.
Toward the ventral side; on the ventral side; ventrally; --opposed to dorsad.
Slightly green; greenish.
A small valvelike process.
Bidding farewell; suitable or designed for an occasion ofleave-taking; as, a valedictory oration.
a. & n. from Vary. Varying hare (Zoöl.), any hare or rabbitwhich becomes white in winter, especially the common hare of theNorthern United States and Canada.
See Van-courier. [Obs.] Shak.
The grantee of a fief, feud, or fee; one who holds land ofsuperior, and who vows fidelity and homage to him; a feudatory; afeudal tenant. Burrill.
A place where wine is sold. [Obs.] Ainsworth.
One of the vessels which carry blood, either venous orarterial, to the heart. See Artery, 2.

A combining form (also used adjectively) indicating derivationfrom, or relation to, valerian or some of its products, as valericacid; as in valerolactone, a colorless oily liquid produced as theanhydride of an hydroxy valeric acid.

A group of minerals having, a micaceous structure. They arehydrous silicates, derived generally from the alteration of some kindof mica. So called because the scales, when heated, open out intowormlike forms.
Pertaining to, or involving, vitalism, or the theory of aspecial vital principle.
The yellow fever in its worst form, when it is usually attendedwith black vomit. See Black vomit.
Of or pertaining to a prophet; prophetical. Bp. Hall.
The condition of a valetudinarian; a state of feeble health;infirmity.
Of or pertaining to Virgil, the Roman poet; resembling thestyle of Virgil. [Spelt also Vergilian.]The rich Virgilian rustic measure Of Lari Maxume. Tennyson.
To call into court to warrant and defend, or to make good awarranty of title.He vouches the tenant in tail, who vouches over the common vouchee.Blackstone.
The act, art, or process of vitrifying; also, the state ofbeing vitrified.
The act of vitiating, or the state of being vitiated;depravation; corruption; invalidation; as, the vitiation of theblood; the vitiation of a contract.The vitiation that breeds evil acts. G. Eliot.
Shaped like a little twig or rod.
Having the nature of a plant; vegetable; as, vegetive life.[R.] Tusser.
Full of veins; veinous; veined; as, veiny marble.
Truth-telling; truthful; veracious. [R.] Carlyle.
Capable of being verified; confirmable. Bp. Hall.
Having twenty-four leaves to a sheet; as, a vigesimo-quartoform, book, leaf, size, etc.

Vanity; emptiness; -- now used only in the phrase in vain. Forvain. See In vain. [Obs.] Shak.-- In vain, to no purpose; without effect; ineffectually. " In vaindoth valor bleed." Milton. " In vain they do worship me." Matt. xv.9.-- To take the name of God in vain, to use the name of God withlevity or profaneness.
The palace of immortality, inhabited by the souls of heroesslain in battle.
Violescent. [R.]
One who vends; one who transfers the exclusive right ofpossessing a thing, either his own, or that of another as his agent,for a price or pecuniary equivalent; a seller; a vendor.
Volcanic. [R.] Keats.
Vacillating; wavering; fluctuating; irresolute.
To make different; to vary; to variegate. [R.] Sylvester.
Of or pertaining to prophecy; prophetic. T. Warton.
The quality or state of being vertical; verticalness. [R.]The different points of the verticality. Sir T. Browne.
A sentinel, usually on horseback, stationed on the outpost ofan army, to watch an enemy and give notice of danger; a vidette.

The answer of a jury given to the court concerning any matterof fact in any cause, civil or criminal, committed to theirexamination and determination; the finding or decision of a jury onthe matter legally submitted to them in the course of the trial of acause.
Light; giddy. [Obs.]They wroughten all their lust volage. Chaucer.
The quality or state of being valid.
Of or pertaining to vines; containing vines. [R.] Sir T.Browne.
Of or pertaining to a vestibule; like a vestibule.

Of or pertaining to Venice in Italy. Venetian blind, a blindfor windows, doors, etc., made of thin slats, either fixed at acertain angle in the shutter, or movable, and in the latter case sodisposed as to overlap each other when close, and to show a series ofopen spaces for the admission of air and light when in otherpositions.-- Venetian carpet, an inexpensive carpet, used for passages andstairs, having a woolen warp which conceals the weft; the pattern istherefore commonly made up of simple stripes.-- Venetian chalk, a white compact or steatite, used for marking oncloth, etc.-- Venetian door (Arch.), a door having long, narrow windows orpanes of glass on the sides.-- Venetian glass, a kind of glass made by the Venetians, fordecorative purposes, by the combination of pieces of glass ofdifferent colors fused together and wrought into various ornamentalpatterns.-- Venetian red, a brownish red color, prepared from sulphate ofiron; -- called also scarlet ocher.-- Venetian soap. See Castile soap, under Soap.-- Venetian sumac (Bot.), a South European tree (Rhus Cotinus) whichyields the yellow dyewood called fustet; -- also called smoke tree.-- Venetian window (Arch.), a window consisting of a main windowwith an arched head, having on each side a long and narrow windowwith a square head.
Of or pertaining to a vein or veins; as, the venous circulationof the blood.

To come to for the purpose of chastising, rewarding,comforting; to come upon with reward or retribution; to appear beforeor judge; as, to visit in mercy; to visit one in wrath.[God] hath visited and redeemed his people. Like i. 68.
Any leguminous plant of the genus Vicia, some species of whichare valuable for fodder. The common species is V. sativa.
The principle of supporting a religious system and itsinstitutions by voluntary association and effort, rather than by theaid or patronage of the state.
A tribe of bats including the common insectivorous bats ofAmerica and Europe, belonging to Vespertilio and allied genera. Theylack a nose membrane.
Poisonous. [Obs.]
Same as Vinnewed.
The smallpox.
The act of laying on varnish; also, materials for varnish.
Any fresh-water gastropod of the genus Valvata.
One who, or that which, verifies.
Causing constriction of the blood vessels; as, thevasoconstrictor nerves, stimulation of which causes constriction ofthe blood vessels to which they go. These nerves are also calledvasohypertonic. n.
The troops who march in front of an army; the advance guard;the van.
The act of beating or whipping. [Obs.]
A word which affirms or predicates something of some person orthing; a part of speech expressing being, action, or the suffering ofaction.

Having the power or habit of turning or twining; as, thevoluble stem of hop plants. Voluble stem (Bot.), a stem that climbsby winding, or twining, round another body.-- Vol"u*ble*ness, n.-- Vol"u*bly, adv.
A veil; a thin covering; also, material for making veils.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, variolite.
The quality or state of being vain.

Any plant of the genus Valeriana. The root of the officinalvalerian (V. officinalis) has a strong smell, and is much used inmedicine as an antispasmodic. Greek valerian (Bot.), a plant(Polemonium cæruleum) with blue or white flowers, and leavesresembling those of the officinal valerian.
One who voyages; one who sails or passes by sea or water.

a. & n. from Vanish, v. Vanishing fraction (Math.), a fractionwhich reduces to the form Math. Dict.-- Vanishing line (Persp.), the intersection of the parallel of anyoriginal plane and picture; one of the lines converging to thevanishing point.-- Vanishing point (Persp.), the point to which all parallel linesin the same plane tend in the representation. Gwilt.-- Vanishing stress (Phon.), stress of voice upon the closingportion of a syllable. Rush.
To glide in a flying machine.
Producing yolk, or vitelline substance; -- applied to certaincells (also called nutritive, or yolk, cells) formed in the ovariesof many insects, and supposed to supply nutriment to the developingova.

The ornament of woodwork upon the gable of a house, usedextensively in the 15th century. It was generally suspended from theedge of the projecting roof (see Verge, n., 4), and in positionparallel to the gable wall. Called also bargeboard.
Having the nature of vinegar; sour; unamiable.
Conveyed in a vehicle; furnished with a vehicle. M. Green.

Act or process of attempting to give an arbitrary market valueor price to a commodity by governmental interference, as bymaintaining a purchasing fund, making loans to producers to enablethem to hold their products, etc.; -- used chiefly of such action byBrazil.
A trembler, as of an electric bell. (2)
An instrument for the exact measurement of electric currents.
Of or pertaining to a vertebræ and an artery; -- said of theforamina in the transverse processes of cervical vertebræ and of thecanal which they form for the vertebral artery and vein.
The act or process of making vulgar, or common.
An old stringed instrument played upon with a wheel; a hurdy-gurdy.
See Vasodilator.
The act of giving validity. [R.] Knowles.
See Vermilion. [R.]
Of or relating to Voltaire, the French author. J. Morley.
The operation of gathering grapes. [Obs.] Bailey.
A ballad. [Obs.] Cotton.
The manufacture of glass and glassware.
Viridity; greenness.
Very; true. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Made or marked with irregular wavy lines or impressions;vermiculate. Vermiculated work, or Vermicular work (Arch.), rusticwork so wrought as to have the appearance of convoluted worms, or ofhaving been eaten into by, or covered with tracks of, worms. Gwilt.
A very fine wavy crosswise color marking, or a patch of suchmarkings, as on the feathers of birds.

One of the changes of assimilation, in which proteid matterwhich has been transformed, and made a part of the tissue or tissuecells, is endowed with life, and thus enabled to manifest thephenomena of irritability, contractility, etc. McKendrick.
The act of vouchsafing, or that which is vouchsafed; a gift orgrant in condescension. Glanvill.
A group of butterflies including those known as virgins, orgossamer-winged butterflies.
To practice ventriloquism; to speak like a ventriloquist.
Having a volute, or spiral scroll.

Any theory which conceives will to be the dominant factor inexperience or in the constitution of the world; -- contrasted withintellectualism. Schopenhauer and Fichte are typical exponents of thetwo types of metaphysical voluntarism, Schopenhauer teaching that theevolution of the universe is the activity of a blind and irrationalwill, Fichte holding that the intelligent activity of the ego is thefundamental fact of reality.
Of or pertaining to the state of a widow; widowed. [R.] Jer.Taylor.
The act of verbalizing, or the state of being verbalized.
Charged with leaves, fruits, flowers, etc.; -- said of aborder.
Widowhood. [R.] "Chaste viduity." Ld. Ellenborough.
A stringed instrument of music; a bass viol of four strings, ora bass violin with long, large strings, giving sounds an octave lowerthan the viola, or tenor or alto violin.
Serving to verify; verifying; authenciating; confirming.
The office of a vicegerent. South.
A voyage; a journey. [Obs.] Chaucer. Gower.
The claiming a thing as one's own; the asserting of a right ortitle in, or to, a thing. Burrill.
A visionary.
Consisting in, or causing, vibration, or oscillation;vibrating; as, a vibratory motion; a vibratory power.

A superior force which under certain circumstances is held toexempt from contract obligations; inevitable accident; -- a civil-lawterm used as nearly equivalent to, but broader than, the common-lawterm act of God (which see).
A genus of small spiral fresh-water gastropods having anoperculum.
In a voluntary manner; of one's own will; spontaneously.
In a vertical manner, position, or direction; perpendicularly;as, to look down vertically; to raise a thing vertically.
Wandering; -- applied especially to the pneumogastric nerve.-- n.

Of or pertaining to a variety; characterizing a variety;constituting a variety, in distinction from an individual or species.Perplexed in determining what differences to consider as specific,and what as varietal. Darwin.

To boast; to make a vain display of one's own worth,attainments, decorations, or the like; to talk ostentatiously; tobrag.Pride, which prompts a man to vaunt and overvalue what he is, doesincline him to disvalue what he has. Gov. of Tongue.
A small villa. [R.]
Movement of vehicles.
One who practices, or is skilled in, ventriloquism.Ventriloquist monkey (Zoöl.), the onappo; -- so called from thecharacter of its cry.
See Viscount.
The hypothetical radical VO, regarded as a characterizedresidue of certain vanadium compounds.
Resembling a varix.
A tribe of birds comprising the sheathbills.
A company of troops under one vexillum.
In a vague manner.What he vaguely hinted at, but dared not speak. Hawthorne.

Of, pertaining to, or designating, certain secret tribunalsflourished in Germany from the end of the 12th century to the middleof the 16th, usurping many of the functions of the government whichwere too weak to maintain law and order, and inspiring dread in allwho came within their jurisdiction. Encyc. Brit.
A lurcher. [Prov. Eng.]
Full of vacuoles, or small air cavities; as, vacuolated cells.
Full of wounds; wounded.
One who vexes or troubles.
That may be vanquished.
An order of court by which a proceeding is set aside orannulled.
Tending to prevent, destroy, or expel, worms or vermin;anthelmintic.
To be irritated; to fret. [R.] Chapman.
A player on the violoncello.
The lowest degree of desire; imperfect or incomplete volition.Locke.

Of or pertaining to the will; subject to, or regulated by, thewill; as, the voluntary motions of an animal, such as the movementsof the leg or arm (in distinction from involuntary motions, such asthe movements of the heart); the voluntary muscle fibers, which arethe agents in voluntary motion.
Same Vedette.
An instrument for measuring the volume or the tension of anyvapor; specifically, an instrument of this sort used as analcoholometer in testing spirituous liquors.

Not sounded with voice; as, a voiceless consonant; surd.Voiceless stop (Phon.), a consonant made with no audible sound exceptin the transition to or from another sound; a surd mute, as p, t, k.-- Voice"less*ly, adv.-- Voice"less*ness, n.
Not perceivable by the eye; invisible; unseen. "Viewlesswinds." Shak.Swift through the valves the visionary fair Repassed, and viewlessmixed with common air. Pope.
Varicose. [Obs.]
A deformity in which the foot is turned inward. See Talipes.
To furnish with a valance; to decorate with hangings ordrapery.His old fringed chair valanced around with party-colored worstedbobs. Sterne.

The degree of combining power of an atom (or radical) as shownby the number of atoms of hydrogen (or of other monads, as chlorine,sodium, etc.) with which it will combine, or for which it can besubstituted, or with which it can be compared; thus, an atom ofhydrogen is a monad, and has a valence of one; the atoms of oxygen,nitrogen, and carbon are respectively dyads, triads, and tetrads, andhave a valence respectively of two, three, and four.
A ditch on the outside of the counterscarp, usually full ofwater.

To regard with reverential respect; to honor with mingledrespect and awe; to reverence; to revere; as, we venerate parents andelders.And seemed to venerate the sacred shade. Dryden.I do not know a man more to be venerated for uprightness of heart andloftiness of genius. Sir W. Scott.
Vinnewed. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]

Any one of numerous species of Old World venomous makesbelonging to Vipera, Clotho, Daboia, and other genera of the familyViperidæ.There came a viper out of the heat, and fastened on his hand. Actsxxviii. 3.
A machine for concentrating ore. See Frue vanner.
One versed in the doctrines of the Vedantas.
A green poisonous substance used as a pigment and drug,obtained by the action of acetic acid on copper, and consistingessentially of a complex mixture of several basic copper acetates.
Venomous. [Obs.]
A Russian drink distilled from rye.
The conversion of a fruit juice or other saccharine solutioninto alcohol by fermentation.
Capable of being vaporized into vapor.
A genus of climbing orchidaceous plants natives of tropicalAmerica.
Having marks or patches of different colors; as, variegatedleaves, or flowers.Ladies like variegated tulips show. Pope.
Having no veins; as, a veinless leaf.
A supposed element, afterward found to be a mixture of severalmetals, as copper, iron, lead, nickel, etc.

A system of characters invented by Prof. Alexander MelvilleBell to represent all sounds that may be uttered by the speechorgans, and intended to be suggestive of the position of the organsof speech in uttering them.
Variolous.
One of the Vertebrata.

A poisonous alkaloid obtained from the root hellebore(Veratrum) and from sabadilla seeds as a white crystalline powder,having an acrid, burning taste. It is sometimes used externally, asin ointments, in the local treatment of neuralgia and rheumatism.Called also veratria, and veratrina.
Pertaining to, derived from, or designating, an acid obtainedfrom a lichen (Cetraria vulpina) as a yellow or red crystallinesubstance which on decomposition yields pulvinic acid.
A dynamite composed of nitroglycerin (30 parts), sodium nitrate(52.5), charcoal (10.5), and sulphur (7), used in mining andblasting.
Capable of being formed into glass; tending to become glass.
The quality of being vaporous.
Vastness. [Obs.]The huge vastity of the world. Holland.
To depart quickly; to depart from. [Written also vamos, andvamoose.] [Slang, Eng. & U. S.]
A little villa. [R.] Gay.

The vassal or tenant of a baron; one who held under a baron,and who also had tenants under him; one in dignity next to a baron; atitle of dignity next to a baron. Burrill. "A worthy vavasour."Chaucer. [Also written vavasour, vavassor, valvasor, etc.]Vavasours subdivide again to vassals, exchanging land and cattle,human or otherwise, against fealty. Motley.
Same as Vestibule  train, under Vestibule.
See Veronica, 1. [Obs.]
The faintest and palest green.
The flesh of a calf when killed and used for food.
A vital part; one of the vitals. [R.]
State of being vagrant; vagrancy.
A vernacular idiom.
A mountain or hill, usually more or less conical in form, fromwhich lava, cinders, steam, sulphur gases, and the like, are ejected;-- often popularly called a burning mountain.
Vulturous.
Same as Veratrine.
An Italian four-wheeled carriage, esp. one let for hire; ahackney coach.
Colloq. contr. of University.
Curtain or covering; -- applied to various membranouspartitions, especially to the soft palate. See under Palate.
Full of venules, or small veins.
The quality or state of being virile; developed manhood;manliness; specif., the power of procreation; as, exhaustion."Virility of visage." Holland.
To cry up. as if for sale; to blazon. [Obs.] Holland.
A vertebra. [Obs.]
The method or process of measuring volumes by means of thevolumenometer.

Resembling a worm in form or motions; vermicular; as, thevermiform process of the cerebellum. Vermiform appendix (Anat.), aslender blind process of the cæcum in man and some other animals; --called also vermiform appendage, and vermiform process. Small solidbodies, such as grape seeds or cherry stones, sometimes lodge in it,causing serious, or even fatal, inflammation. See Illust. underDigestion.
The council held under Pope Pius IX. in Vatican at Rome, in1870, which promulgated the dogma of papal infallibility.
To render volatile; to cause to exhale or evaporate; to causeto pass off in vapor.The water . . . dissolving the oil, and volatilizing it by theaction. Sir I. Newton.
A vigil. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A visitor.
A salt of valeric acid with glycerin, occurring in butter,dolphin oil., and forming an forming an oily liquid with a slightlyunpleasant odor.
Of or pertaining to the viscount or sheriff of a country.Vicontiel rents. See Vicontiels.-- Vicontiel writs, such writs as were triable in the sheriff, orcounty, court.
Of or pertaining to a verse.
Having the qualities of a viper; malignant; venomous; as, aviperous tongue. "This viperous slander." Shak.-- Vi"per*ous*ly, adv.
Moldy; musty. [Written also vinewed.] [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] --Vin"newed*ness, n. [Obs.]Many of Chaucer's words are become, as it were, vinnewed and hoarywith over-long lying. F. Beaumont.

Of or pertaining to the fox; resembling the fox; foxy; cunning;crafty; artful. Vulpine phalangist (Zoöl.), an Australian carnivorousmarsupial (Phalangista, or Trichosurus, vulpina); -- called alsovulpine phalanger, and vulpine opossum.
The brush turkey (Talegallus Lathami) of Australia. See Brushturkey.
To make into a verb; to use as a verb; to verbalize. [R.]Earle.
An electrotype. [R.]
To vault; to leap. [Obs.] Spenser.
A genus of very large lizards native of Asia and Africa. Itincludes the monitors. See Monitor, 3.
Verisimilar. [Obs.]

A calling by the will of God. Specifically: --(a) The bestowment of God's distinguishing grace upon a person ornation, by which that person or nation is put in the way ofsalvation; as, the vocation of the Jews under the old dispensation,and of the Gentiles under the gospel. "The golden chain of vocation,election, and justification." Jer. Taylor.(b) A call to special religious work, as to the ministry.Every member of the same [the Church], in his vocation and ministry.Bk. of Com. Prayer.
A greenish chloritic mineral common in certain igneous rocks,as diabase, as a result of alternation.
Vermeil. [Obs.] Spenser.
The act of gathering the vintage, or crop of grapes.
To convert into vapor, as by the application of heat, whethernaturally or artificially. Vaporizing surface. (Steam Boilers) SeeEvaporating surface, under Evaporate, v. t.

A white crystalline aldehyde having a burning taste andcharacteristic odor of vanilla. It is extracted from vanilla pods,and is also obtained by the decomposition of coniferin, and by theoxidation of eugenol.
The condition, pursuits, or occupation of a virtuoso. Bp. Hurd.
Making a loud outcry; clamorous; noisy; as, vociferous heralds.-- Vo*cif"er*ous*ly, adv.-- Vo*cif"er*ous*ness, n.
A complex nitrogenous substance, produced as a yellowcrystalline substance, and regarded as a complex derivative ofbarbituric acid.
The venereal disease; syphilis.
The act of vitriolizing, or the state of being vitriolized;vitriolation.
Of no legal force or effect, incapable of confirmation orratification; null. Cf. Voidable, 2. Void space (Physics), a vacuum.
One who strolls from place to place; one who has no settledhabitation; an idle wanderer; a sturdy beggar; an incorrigible rogue;a vagabond.Vagrants and outlaws shall offend thy view. Prior.
Receiving what is ejected or voided. "How in our voiding lobbyhast thou stood" Shak.
To wit; that is; namely.
Neighborhood; vicinity; venue. See Venue.
Partaking of the nature both of vegetable and animal matter; --a term sometimes applied to vegetable albumen and gluten, from theirresemblance to similar animal products.
The goddess of rural leisure, to whom the husbandmen sacrificedat the close of the harvest. She was especially honored by theSabines.
One who vails. [Obs.] Overbury.
pl. of Viscus.
A gab at the end of an eccentric rod, with long jaws, shapedlike the letter V.
Having a valve or valve; valvate.
The state of being widowed or bereaved; loss; bereavement. [R.]

Plants having distinct flowers and true seeds. { 1.Dicotyledons (called also Exogens).-- Seeds with two or more cotyledons. Stems with the pith, woodyfiber, and bark concentrically arranged. Divided into two subclasses:Angiosperms, having the woody fiber interspersed with dotted orannular ducts, and the seed contained in a true ovary; Gymnosperms,having few or no ducts in the woody fiber, and the seeds naked. 2.Monocotyledons (called also Endogens).-- Seeds with single cotyledon. Stems with slender bundles of woodyfiber not concentrically arranged, and with no true bark.} II.Cryptogamia.
Fawning or obsequious behavior; servility. [R.] Bailey.
To strew with verbena, or vervain, as in ancient sacrifices andrites.
A vehmic court.
As much as a vat will hold; enough to fill a vat.
In a vital manner.
A vegetable. [R.] B. Jonson.

True; real; actual; veritable.Whether thou be my very son Esau or not. Gen. xxvii. 21.He that covereth a transgression seeketh love; but he that repeatetha matter separateth very friends. Prov. xvii. 9.The very essence of truth is plainness and brightness. Milton.I looked on the consideration of public service or public ornament tobe real and very justice. Burke.
That may be sailed over, as water or air; navigable.
An alkaloid obtained as a yellow amorphous substance by thedecomposition of veratrine.
A painful spasmodic contraction of the vagina, often renderingcopulation impossible.
The quality of being vocal; vocality.
The campanularian medusæ.
The quality or state of being voluble (in any of the senses ofthe adjective).
Long live, that is, success to; as, vive le roi, long live theking; vive la bagatelle, success to trifles or sport.
Of or pertaining to Vesta, the virgin goddess of the hearth;hence, pure; chaste.
A wind associated with a volcanic outburst and due to theeruption or to convection currents over hot lava.
A coating of long, slender hairs.
Pertaining to life; vital. [R.]
One who rides on a velocipede.
Same as Ascidium, n., 1.
A cupping glass. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To change direction; to turn; to shift; as, wind veers to thewest or north. "His veering gait." Wordsworth.And as he leads, the following navy veers. Dryden.an ordinary community which is hostile or friendly as passion or asinterest may veer about. Burke.To veer and haul (Naut.), to vary the course or direction; -- said ofthe wind, which veers aft and hauls forward. The wind is also said toveer when it shifts with the sun.
To convert into vinegar; to make like vinegar; to render souror sharp. [Obs.]Hoping that he hath vinegared his senses As he was bid. B. Jonson.
A salt of valeric acid.
The act of vituperating; abuse; severe censure; blame.When a man becomes untractable and inaccessible by fierceness andpride, then vituperation comes upon him. Donne.
Of or pertaining to a vision.
A straight, horizontal mark placed over two or more members ofa compound quantity, which are to be subjected to the same operation,as in the expression x2 + y2 - x + y.
The quality or state of being veracious; habitual observance oftruth; truthfulness; truth; as, a man of veracity.

Of or pertaining to calling; used in calling; specifically(Gram.), used in address; appellative; -- said of that case or formof the noun, pronoun, or adjective, in which a person or thing isaddressed; as, Domine, O Lord.
A dry white wine, of a tart flavor, produced in Teneriffe; --called also Teneriffe.
Somewhat viscous. Cf. Mobile, a., 2.
To investigate. [Obs.]
Noisy; clamorous. Gauden. R. Browning.

One who carries a verge, or emblem of office. Specifically: --(a) An attendant upon a dignitary, as on a bishop, a dean, a justice,etc. [Eng.] Strype.(b) The official who takes care of the interior of a church building.
The third of the four great original castes among the Hindoos,now either extinct or partially represented by the mercantile classof Banyas. See the Note under Caste, 1.
The quality or state of being verdant.
Arched; concave. [Obs.] "The vaulty heaven." Shak.
A disease of brute animals, especially of horses, seated in theglands under the ear, where a tumor is formed which sometimes ends insuppuration.
The office or dignity of a vicar.
Volcanic power or action; volcanicity.
Vitriolated. [R.]
An infective sore mostly on the hands and feet, oftencontracted in walking on the veldt and apparently due to a specificmicroörganism.
See Waywode. Longfellow.

A tract of low ground, or of land between hills; a valley. "Make me a cottage in the vale." Tennyson.Beyond this vale of tears there is a life above. Montgomery.In those fair vales, by nature formed to please. Harte.
In a vulgar manner.
One skilled in the diseases of cattle or domestic animals; aveterinary surgeon.
An officer who formerly supplied the place of the count, orearl; the sheriff of the county.
The quality or state of being vitreous.
The act or practice of poisoning. [Obs.]
Any species of oceanic Siphonophora belonging to the genusVelella.
Vindictive; retributive; revengeful. "Vengeful ire." Milton.-- Venge"ful*ly, adv.
A genus of motile bacteria characterized by short, slightlysinuous filaments and an undulatory motion; also, an individual ofthis genus.
One who venerates. Jer. Taylor

Of or pertaining to a viper or vipers; resembling a viper.Viperine snake. (Zoöl.) (a) Any venomous snake of the familyViperidæ. (b) A harmless snake resembling a viper in form or color,esp. Tropidonotus viperinus, a small European species which resemblesthe viper in color.
Formation into, or multiplication of, vacuoles.

To express or signify the mind, will, or preference, eitherviva voce, or by ballot, or by other authorized means, as in electingpersons to office, in passing laws, regulations, etc., or in decidingon any proposition in which one has an interest with others.The vote for a duelist is to assist in the prostration of justice,and, indirectly, to encourage the crime. L. Beecher.To vote on large principles, to vote honestly, requires a greatamount of information. F. W. Robertson.
One who strongly adheres to the papal authority; anultramontanist.
Of or pertaining to a vehicle; serving as a vehicle; as, avehicular contrivance.

The quality or state of being vivacious. Specifically: --(a) Tenacity of life; vital force; natural vigor. [Obs.] The vivacityof some of these pensioners is little less than a miracle, they livedso long. Fuller.
A victress. [R.] B. Jonson.
So as to be of value.
Worthy of vituperation; shameful; disgraceful. [Obs.]
A small vein; a veinlet; specifically (Zoöl.), one of the smallbranches of the veins of the wings in insects.
A woman who is a votary. Shak.
Revengeful; deserving revenge. [Obs.] Spenser.-- Venge"a*bly, adv. [Obs.]
A genus scrophulariaceous plants; the speedwell. See Speedwell.

Capable of being avoided, or of being adjudged void, invalid,and of no force; capable of being either avoided or confirmed.If the metropolitan . . . grants letters of administration, suchadministration is not, but voidable by sentence. Ayliffe.

The act of venerating, or the state of being venerated; thehighest degree of respect and reverence; respect mingled with awe; afeeling or sentimental excited by the dignity, wisdom, or superiorityof a person, by sacredness of character, by consecration to sacredservices, or by hallowed associations.We find a secret awe and veneration for one who moves about us inregular and illustrious course of virtue. Addison.
Of or pertaining to a journey or traveling.
A versifier. B. Jonson.
Capable of being vitrified, or converted into glass by heat andfusion; as, flint and alkalies are vitrifiable.
The diadem indris. See Indris.
A vertical line, plane, or circle. Prime vertical, Primevertical dial. See under Prime, a.
Value. [Obs.] Ld. Berners.
Of or pertaining to the Vedas.
Of or pertaining to a vixen; resembling a vixen.
See Vanquish, n.
See Voe. [Scot.]
Vaulted. "The haughty vauty welkin." [Obs.] Taylor (1611).
Same as Vugg.
Vastness; immensity. [Obs.] "All the world's vastidity." Shak.
A light cape or short cloak of silk or lace worn by women insummer.
One who practices or advocates vivisection; a vivisector.
In Continental armies, esp. the French, a sutler.
Same as Viscacha.
Pertaining to a gulf; full of gulfs; hence, devouring. [R.]Mallet.

A light road carriage propelled by the feet of the rider.Originally it was propelled by striking the tips of the toes on theroadway, but commonly now by the action of the feet on a pedal orpedals connected with the axle of one or more of the wheels, andcausing their revolution. They are made in many forms, with two,three, or four wheels. See Bicycle, and Tricycle.
To supply with provisions for subsistence; to provide withfood; to store with sustenance; as, to victual an army; to victual aship.I must go victual Orleans forthwith. Shak.
A game played by volleying a large inflated ball with the handsover a net 7 ft. 6 in. high.

In Ireland, a national school which has been built by the aidof grants from the board of Commissioners of National Education andis secured for educational purposes by leases to the commissionersthemselves, or to the commissioners and the trustees.
The four-colored flag of the South African Republic, orTransvaal, -- red, white, blue, and green.
A yellow crystalline glucoside obtained from the pansy (Violatricolor), and decomposing into glucose and quercitrin.
Vegetal state or characteristic.
Chromate of copper and lead, of various shades of green.

A covering or garment; some part of clothing or dress;specifically (Eccl.), any priestly garment. "Royal vestiment."Chaucer. "Priests in holy vestments." Shak.The sculptor could not give vestments suitable to the quality of thepersons represented. Dryden.
To make a vow, or solemn promise.Better is it that thou shouldest not vow, than that thou shouldestvow and not pay. Eccl. v. 5.
Capable of being turned. [R.]

A vocal, or sometimes a whispered, sound modified by resonancein the oral passage, the peculiar resonance in each case giving toeach several vowel its distinctive character or quality as a sound ofspeech; -- distinguished from a consonant in that the latter, whethermade with or without vocality, derives its character in every casefrom some kind of obstructive action by the mouth organs. Also, aletter or character which represents such a sound. See Guide toPronunciation, §§ 5, 146-149.
Somewhat like a viper; viperous.
The writer or maker of a vocabulary; a lexicographer.
The murder, or the murderer, of a prophet. "The caitiffvaticide." Pope.
The first game after the set is deuce. See Set, n., 9.
Any one of numerous species of club-shaped, compound Alcyonariabelonging to Veretillum and allied genera, of the tribe Pennatulacea.The whole colony can move about as if it were a simple animal.
A wandering; vagrancy. [Obs.]A thousand vagancies of glory and desight. Milton.
To infect with venom; to envenom; to poison. [R.] "Venomedvengeance." Shak.
Of or pertaining to vowel sounds; consisting of the vowelsounds. Earle.The Gaelic language being uncommonly vocalic. Sir W. Scott.
A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, a vertebra, vertebræ, or vertebral column; as invertebrocostal.
A glucoside extracted from the root of a South African plant ofthe genus Vernonia, as a deliquescent powder, and used as a mildheart tonic.
The fore part; van. [Obs.]Since we have the vaward of the day. Shak.
Of or pertaining to the vicuña; characterizing the vicuña; --said of the wool of that animal, used in felting hats, and for otherpurposes. Prescott.
imperative sing. of L. videre, to see; -- used to directattention to something; as, vide supra, see above.
a. & n. from Vie.-- Vy"ing*ly, adv.
In a vain manner; in vain.
Vibrating; tremulous; resonant; as, vibrant drums. Longfellow.
A native attorney or agent; also, an ambassador. [India]
A poem written in tercets with but two rhymes, the first andthird verse of the first stanza alternating as the third verse ineach successive stanza and forming a couplet at the close. E. W.Gosse.

Given by vow, or in fulfillment of a vow; consecrated by a vow;devoted; as, votive offerings; a votive tablet. "Votive incense."Keble.We reached a votive stone, that bears the name Of Aloys Reding.Wordsworth.Embellishments of flowers and votive garlands. Motley.Votive medal, a medal struck in grateful commemoration of someauspicious event.-- Votive offering, an offering in fulfillment of a religious vow,as of one's person or property.-- Vo"tive*ly, adv.-- Vo"tive*ness, n.
One of the chief administrative divisions or provinces of theOttoman Empire; -- formerly called eyalet.
Same as Nux vomica.
To transfer to another person for a pecuniary equivalent; tomake an object of trade; to dispose of by sale; to sell; as, to vendgoods; to vend vegetables.
The 95th Psalm, which is said or sung regularly in the publicworship of many churches. Also, a musical composition adapted to thisPsalm.
Of or pertaining to words; verbal. [R.] Coleridge.

Worth estimated by any standard of purchasing power, especiallyby the market price, or the amount of money agreed upon as anequivalent to the utility and cost of anything.An article may be possessed of the highest degree of utility, orpower to minister to our wants and enjoyments, and may be universallymade use of, without possessing exchangeable value. M'Culloch.Value is the power to command commodities generally. A. L. Chapin(Johnson's Cys.).Value is the generic term which expresses power in exchange. F. A.Walker.His design was not to pay him the value of his pictures, because theywere above any price. Dryden.
A vorticella.
The incumbent of an appropriated benefice.
To convert into a vitriol; to vitriolate.
Verrucose.
A valuable kind of pear, of an obovate shape and with meltingflesh of delicious flavor; -- more properly called White Doyenné.[Written also virgaloo, vergalieu, vergaloo, etc.]
The goddess of beauty and love, that is, beauty or lovedeified.
A sprig or branch. [Archaic] Halliwell.
The fieldfare. [Prov. Eng.]
The doctrine of papal supremacy; extreme views in support ofthe authority of the pope; ultramontanism; -- a term used only bypersons who are not Roman Catholics.
Of or pertaining to the art of healing or treating the diseasesof domestic animals, as oxen, horses, sheep, etc.; as, a veterinarywriter or school.
A small collection of houses; a village. "Every manor, town, orvill." Sir M. Hale.Not should e'er the crested fowl From thorp or vill his matins soundfor me. Wordsworth.
The terminal part of the oviduct in insects and various otherinvertebrates. See Illust., of Spermatheca.
One of many textile fabrics having a pile like that of velvet.
To prophesy; to foretell; to practice prediction; to utterprophecies.
A volcano. [Obs.]

The faculty of seeing; sight; one of the five senses, by whichcolors and the physical qualities of external objects are appreciatedas a result of the stimulating action of light on the sensitiveretina, an expansion of the optic nerve.
The office, dignity, or authority of a vizier.
In the greater part of Russia, a division for local governmentconsisting of a group of mirs, or village communities; a canton.
To wound; to hurt. [Obs.]
The acid amide derivative of valeric acid, obtained as a whitecrystalline substance.

Of or pertaining to a natural order (Verbenaceæ) ofgamopetalous plants of which Verbena is the type. The order includesalso the black and white mangroves, and many plants noted formedicinal use or for beauty of bloom.
Vociferation; noise; clamor. [R.] R. Browning.

Any one of several species of actinians belonging to the genusCerianthus. These animals have a long, smooth body tapering to thebase, and two separate circles of tentacles around the mouth. Theyform a tough, flexible, feltlike tube with a smooth internal lining,in which they dwell, whence the name.

A love of the fine arts; a taste for curiosities. J. Spence. Anarticle, or piece, of virtu, an object of art or antiquity; acuriosity, such as those found in museums or private collections.I had thoughts, in my chambers to place it in view, To be shown to myfriends as a piece of virtù. Goldsmith.
Things belonging to the sheriff; especially, farms (called alsovicontiel rents) for which the sheriff used to pay rent to the king.
One of the serial segments of the spinal column.
Hard rubber produced by vulcanizing with a large proportion ofsulphur.
A passage for wind or air; a passage or pipe for ventilatingapartments. Gwilt.
Vigorous; energetic; with energy; -- a direction to perform apassage with energy and force.
One who assesses, or sets a value on, anything; an appraiser.Swift.
One engaged in viticulture.

The act of vociferating; violent outcry; vehement utterance ofthe voice.Violent gesture and vociferation naturally shake the hearts of theignorant. Spectator.Plaintive strains succeeding the vociferations of emotion or of pain.Byron.
A farewell; a bidding farewell. Donne.
A vesicle.
The quality or state of being vincible, vincibleness.
Wandering; unsettled. [Obs.] Ayliffe.
The act of setting forth ostentatiously; a boastful display.[Obs.] B. Jonson.
Having a nauseous odor; fetid; poisonous. [R.]
Sexual love; sexual intercourse; coition.Contentment, without the pleasure of lawful venery, is continence; ofunlawful, chastity. Grew.
Same as Vallar.
To invigorate. [Obs.] Feltham.
Valetudinarian. [Obs.] "The valetudinous condition of KingEdward." Fuller.
A vial. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Iliolumbar.
An instrument consisting of two jaws, closing by a screw,lever, cam, or the like, for holding work, as in filing. [Writtenalso vice.]
Of or pertaining to the sight; visual. [Obs.]I can not satisfy myself how men should be so little surprised aboutthis visive faculty. Berkeley.
A grand vizier. See under Vizier.
Possessing or exhibiting valor; brave; courageous; valiant;intrepid.-- Val"or*ous*ly, adv.
Wine, --chiefly used in Pharmacy in the name of solutions ofsome medicinal substance in wine; as: vina medicata, medicated wines;vinum opii, wine of opium.
An imaginary tube within a rotating fluid, formed by drawingthe vortex lines through all points of a closed curve.
See Valencia.
Having a poison gland or glands for the secretion of venom, ascertain serpents and insects.

One of the grand divisions of the animal kingdom, comprisingall animals that have a backbone composed of bony or cartilaginousvertebræ, together with Amphioxus in which the backbone isrepresented by a simple undivided notochord. The Vertebrata alwayshave a dorsal, or neural, cavity above the notochord or backbone, anda ventral, or visceral, cavity below it. The subdivisions or classesof Vertebrata are Mammalia, Aves, Reptilia, Amphibia, Pisces,Marsipobranchia, and Leptocardia.

A neighborhood or near place; the place or county in whichanything is alleged to have happened; also, the place where an actionis laid.The twelve men who are to try the cause must be of the same venuewhere the demand is made. Blackstone.
An instrument for determining the strength or purity of wine bymeasuring its density.
A quantity which may increase or decrease; a quantity whichadmits of an infinite number of values in the same expression; avariable quantity; as, in the equation x2 - y2 = R2, x and y arevariables.
The reverse, or left-hand, page of a book or a folded sheet ofpaper; -- opposed to recto.
The office of the vigintiviri, a body of officers of governmentconsisting of twenty men; also, the vigintiviri. [R.]
In a vernacular manner; in the vernacular. Earle.
Adhesive or sticky, and having a ropy or glutinous consistency;viscid; glutinous; clammy; tenacious; as, a viscous juice.-- Vis"cous*ness, n.
A genus of Hymenoptera including the common wasps and hornets.
One who vociferates, or is clamorous. [R.]
A small vein.
Verdict. Chaucer.
A legislative assembly or parliament of any one of severalcountries colonized by the Dutch, esp. that of the South AfricanRepublic, or the Transvaal, and that of the Orange Free State.
Having the form of a vessel, or duct. Vasiform tissue (Bot.),tissue containing vessels, or ducts.
An inhabitant of a village.Brutus had rather be a villager Than to repute himself a son of RomeUnder these hard condition. Shak.
A vortex tube of infinitesimal cross section.
Disesteem; slight; disparagement. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
; vibratory. "A vibrative motion." Sir I. Newton.
To fade; hence, to vanish. [Obs.] " Summer leaves all vaded."Shak.They into dust shall vade. Spenser.

One of a Teutonic race, formerly dwelling on the south shore ofthe Baltic, the most barbarous and fierce of the northern nationsthat plundered Rome in the 5th century, notorious for destroying themonuments of art and literature.
To advance. [Obs.] Spenser.

The flour of a hard and small-grained wheat made into dough,and forced through small cylinders or pipes till it takes a slender,wormlike form, whence the Italian name. When the paste is made inlarger tubes, it is called macaroni.
See Vis.
A Russian liquid measure, equal to 3.249 gallons of U.S.standard measure, or 2.706 imperial gallons. McElrath.

A supposed collection of particles of very subtile matter,endowed with a rapid rotary motion around an axis which was also theaxis of a sun or a planet. Descartes attempted to account for theformation of the universe, and the movements of the bodies composingit, by a theory of vortices.
A circle either of leaves or flowers about a stem at the samenode; a whorl. [Written also verticel.]
One of the ordinaries, much like the flanch, but less roundedand therefore smaller.
Like or pertaining to the vipers.
Having thickset tufts of parallel hairs, bristles, or branches.
Producing vapor; tending to pass, or to cause to pass, intovapor; thus, volatile fluids are vaporific; heat is a vaporificagent.
The marginal membrane of certain medusæ belonging to theDiscophora.
The rhachis and web of a feather taken together.
Legal strength, force, or authority; that quality of a thingwhich renders it supportable in law, or equity; as, the validity of awill; the validity of a contract, claim, or title.
A little valve or fold; a valvelet; a valvule.
Any tube or canal in which the blood or other fluids arecontained, secreted, or circulated, as the arteries, veins,lymphatics, etc.
A brilliant star of the first magnitude, the brightest of thoseconstituting the constellation Lyra.
The reciprocal of the focal distance of a lens, used as measureof the divergence or convergence of a pencil of rays. [R.] HumphreyLloyd.
The calyx of a plant.

A short scale made to slide along the divisions of a graduatedinstrument, as the limb of a sextant, or the scale of a barometer,for indicating parts of divisions. It is so graduated that a certainconvenient number of its divisions are just equal to a certainnumber, either one less or one more, of the divisions of theinstrument, so that parts of a division are determined by observingwhat line on the vernier coincides with a line on the instrument.Vernier calipers, Vernier gauge, a gauge with a graduated bar and asliding jaw bearing a vernier, used for accurate measurements.-- Vernier compass, a surveyor's compass with a vernier for theaccurate adjustment of the zero point in accordance with magneticvariation.-- Vernier transit, a surveyor's transit instrument with a verniercompass.

Pertaining to, or obtained from, vanadium; containing vanadium;specifically distinguished those compounds in which vanadium has arelatively higher valence as contrasted with the vanadious compounds;as, vanadic oxide. Vanadic acid (Chem.), an acid analogous tophosphoric acid, not known in the free state but forming a well-knownseries of salts.
A mask. See Visor.
A wattmeter.
A vivarium. "That . . . vivary of fowls and beasts." Donne.
A wanderer; one who strays in search of variety. [Poetic]Pious variers from the church. Tennyson.
Performance to, or obtained from, valerian root; specifically,designating an acid which is usually called valeric acid.
An odometer; -- called also viatometer.
In a virtual manner; in efficacy or effect only, and notactually; to all intents and purposes; practically.
One of the wedgelike stones of which an arch is composed.
A substance in which medicine is taken.
A voluptuous person; one who makes his physical enjoyment hischief care; one addicted to luxury, and the gratification of sensualappetites.A good-humored, but hard-hearted, voluptuary. Sir W. Scott.
A South African monkey (Cercopithecus pygerythrus, orLelandii). The upper parts are grayish green, finely specked withblack. The cheeks and belly are reddish white.
Verily; truly. [Obs.] Chaucer.

An open, roofed gallery or portico, adjoining a dwelling house,forming an out-of-door sitting room. See Loggia.The house was of adobe, low, with a wide veranda on the three sidesof the inner court. Mrs. H. H. Jackson.
Capable of being volatilized.
A woman who wins a victory; a female victor.
A veil. [Obs.] Spenser.
An alkaloid extracted from the shoots of the vetch, red clover,etc., as a white crystalline substance.

Of or pertaining to the measurement of volume. Volumetricanalysis (Chem.), that system of the quantitative analysis ofsolutions which employs definite volumes of standardized solutions ofreagents, as measured by burettes, pipettes, etc.; also, the analysisof gases by volume, as by the eudiometer.
A groove; a fossa; as, the vallecula, or fossa, which separatesthe hemispheres of the cerebellum.
The dignity or jurisdiction of a viscount. Sir B. Burke.
To tell in verse, or poetry. [Obs.]Playing on pipes of corn and versing love. Shak.
A game at cards, played by two or more persons. The fortune ofeach player depends upon obtaining from the dealer such cards thatthe sum of their pips, or spots, is twenty-one, or a number near toit.
An imperfection on the inside of the hind leg in horses,different from a curb, but at the same height, and frequentlyinjuring the sale of the animal by growing to an unsightly size.Craig.
The quality or tenure of the fee held by a vavasor; also, thelands held by a vavasor.
One who violates; an infringer; a profaner; a ravisher.
Vicious; corrupt. [Obs.] Shak.
Of or pertaining to wine; as, vinic alcohol.

Sound of the kind or quality heard in speech or song in theconsonants b, v, d, etc., and in the vowels; sonant, or intonated,utterance; tone; -- distinguished from mere breath sound as heard inf, s, sh, etc., and also whisper.
A kind of diorite or diabase containing imbedded whitishspherules, which give the rock a spotted appearance.
An instrument for measuring the volume of a body, especially asolid, by means of the difference in tension caused by its presenceand absence in a confined portion of air.
To baptize; -- used in contempt by the Reformers. [Obs.]Tyndale.
The quality of being cunning like the fox; craft; artfulness.[R.]He was without guile, and had no vulpinism at all. Carlyle.
One who treks before or first; a pioneer. [South Africa]
Of or pertaining to the palm of the hand or the sole of thefoot.
The act or process of volatilizing, or rendering volatile; thestate of being volatilized.
A genus of terrestrial gastropods, having transparent, verythin, and delicate shells, -- whence the name.
One who vaults; a leaper; a tumbler. B. Jonson.
Same as Vansire.
Causing the ejection of matter from the stomach; emetic.
Victuals; food. [R.] "With my cargo of victualage." C. Bronté.
To convey by means of a vehicle; to ride in a vehicle. Carlyle.
A name given to several plants which have soft, velvety leaves,as the Abutilon Avicennæ, the Cissampelos Pareira, and the Lavateraarborea, and even the common mullein.
A book or other thing that a person carries with him as aconstant companion; a manual; a handbook.
One who values; an appraiser.
Same as Voucher, 3 (b).
The quality or state of being viewy, or of having unpracticalviews.
Vain or foolish talk. [Obs.]

A councilor of state; a high executive officer in Turkey andother Oriental countries. [Written also visier, vizir, and vizer.]Grand vizier, the chief minister of the Turkish empire; -- calledalso vizier-azem.
The quality or state of being vital; the principle of life;vital force; animation; as, the vitality of eggs or vegetable seeds;the vitality of an enterprise.
Furnished with a virole or viroles; -- said of a horn or abugle when the rings are of different tincture from the rest of thehorn.
The act, process, or result of vitriolating.
Of or pertaining to Vesuvius, a volcano near Naples.
A point giving advantage; vantage ground.
In falconry, one of the rings secured to the ends of thejesses. [Written also vervel.]
Capable of being vindicated.-- Vin`di*ca*bil"i*ty, n.

The theory, advanced by Thomson (Lord Kelvin) on the basis ofinvestigation by Helmholtz, that the atoms are vortically movingring-shaped masses (or masses of other forms having a similarinternal motion) of a homogeneous, incompressible, frictionlessfluid. Various properties of such atoms (vortex atoms) can bemathematically deduced.
To make verses.I'll versify in spite, and do my best. Dryden.
An apple-green mineral occurring in reniform masses. It is ahydrous phosphate of alumina.
In a venal manner.
See Waywode.
A round of iron on the shaft of a tilting spear, to protect thehand. [Written also vamplet.]
The pudu.
Having different shapes or forms.
A mineral occurring in small six-sided tabular crystals of agreen or yellow color. It is a hydrous vanadate of copper and lime.
Capable of being converted into vapor by the agency of heat;vaporizable.
Vaulted work; also, a vaulted place; an arched cellar. [Obs.]Shak.

A contrivance for effecting ventilation; especially, acontrivance or machine for drawing off or expelling foul or stagnantair from any place or apartment, or for introducing that which isfresh and pure.
A genus including several species of large marine gastropodshaving massive pyriform shells, with conspicuous folds on thecolumella.
Crafty; cunning; sly; as, vafrous tricks. [Obs.] Feltham.
A feeder; an eater; also, one who provides viands, or food; ahost. [Obs.] Holinshed.
The quality or state of being vinous.
To take a voyage; especially, to sail or pass by water.A mind forever Voyaging through strange seas of thought alone.Wordsworth.
An instrument for comparing magnetic forces, esp. in theearth's magnetic field.
Vigilance. [Obs.] Fuller.
To beat; to strike. [Obs.] "The sound . . . rebounds again andverberates the skies." Mir. for Mag.
Of or pertaining to the bladder. Dunglison.
A genus of coarse liliaceous herbs having very poisonousqualities.
Face; countenance. [Colloq.] Spenser. Lamb.
Volcanic.
A form of machine for exhibiting animated pictures.
In Continental armies, especially in the French army, a womanaccompanying a regiment, who sells provisions and liquor to thesoldiers; a female sutler.
A public sale of anything, by outcry, to the highest bidder; anauction. [Obsoles.] Vendue master, one who is authorized to sell anyproperty by vendue; an auctioneer. [Obsoles.]
Inoculation with smallpox.
Poisonous; venomous. [Obs.]

An ancient French song, or short poem, wholly in two rhymes,and composed in short lines, with a refrain.Of such matter made he many lays, Songs, complains, roundels,virelayes. Chaucer.To which a lady sung a virelay. Dryden.

The act of violating, treating with violence, or injuring; thestate of being violated. Specifically: --(a) Infringement; transgression; nonobservance; as, the violation oflaw or positive command, of covenants, promises, etc. "The violationof my faith." Shak.(b) An act of irreverence or desecration; profanation or contemptuoustreatment of sacred things; as, the violation of a church. Udall.(c) Interruption, as of sleep or peace; disturbance.(d) Ravishment; rape; outrage. Shak.
Of or pertaining to vivisection.
A probable chemical element discovered by Sir William Crookesin 1898. Its nitrate is obtained byy practical decomposition andcrystallization of yttrium nitrate. At. wt., about 117.
Agreeable to truth or to fact; actual; real; true; genuine."The veritable Deity." Sir W. Hamilton.-- Ver"i*ta*bly, adv.
One of the Northmen who founded a dynasty in Russia in the 9thcentury; also, one of the Northmen composing, at a later date, theimperial bodyguard at Constantinople.
A very handsome American butterfly (Polygonia interrogationis).Its wings are mottled with various shades of red and brown and haveviolet tips.
A dispute or contest; a slight contest; a skirmish. [R.] Sir M.Hale.After a short velitation we parted. Evelyn.
One who vapors; a braggart. Vaporer moth. (Zoöl.) See Orgyia.
Of or pertaining to a virago; having the qualities of a virago.Milton.
Of or pertaining to vanadium; obtained from vanadium; -- saidof an acid containing one equivalent of vanadium and two of oxygen.
The first month of the French republican calendar, dating fromSeptember 22, 1792.
A little valve; a valvule; especially, one of the pieces whichcompose the outer covering of a pericarp.
One who kills a fox, except in hunting; also, the act of sokilling a fox. [Written also vulpecide.]
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, plants of a natural order(Valerianaccæ) of which the valerian is the type. The order includesalso the corn salads and the oriental spikenard.

To overlay or plate with a thin layer of wood or other materialfor outer finish or decoration; as, to veneer a piece of furniturewith mahogany. Used also figuratively.As a rogue in grain Veneered with sanctimonious theory. Tennyson.
One who carried out the dead bodies of the poor at night forburial.Like vespilloes or grave makers. Sir T. Browne.
Sale; opportunity to sell; market. [Obs.] Shelton.There is no vent for any commodity but of wool. Sir W. Temple.

The defeat of an enemy in battle, or of an antagonist in anycontest; a gaining of the superiority in any struggle or competition;conquest; triumph; -- the opposite of Ant: defeat.Death is swallowed up in victory. 1 Cor. xv. 54.God on our side, doubt not of victory. Shak.Victory may be honorable to the arms, but shameful to the counsels,of a nation. Bolingbroke.
A small assemblage of houses in the country, less than a townor city. Village cart, a kind of two-wheeled pleasure carriagewithout a top.
Any one of several species of marine gastropods belonging toVelutina and allied genera.
Arched like the roof of the mouth, as the upper lip of manyringent flowers.
A small sack or case, usually of leather, but sometimes ofother material, for containing the clothes, toilet articles, etc., ofa traveler; a traveling bag; a portmanteau.
A worshiper of the god Vishnu in any of his incarnations.
Of or pertaining to voltaic electricity, or voltaism.
Same as Ventriloquism.
A false wall; a work raised in front of the main wall. [Writtenalso vaimure, and vamure.] Camden.
A running ornament consisting of leaves and tendrils, used inGothic architecture.
A contest for superiority; competition; rivalry; strife; also,a challenge; a wager. [Obs.]We 'll all to church together instantly, And then a vie for boys. J.Fletcher.

A yellowish translucent substance, almost odorless andtasteless, obtained as a residue in the purification of crudepetroleum, and consisting essentially of a mixture of several of thehigher members of the paraffin series. It is used as an unguent, andfor various purposes in the arts. See the Note under Petrolatum.[Written also vaselin.]
A glucoside extracted from the root of the white swallowwort(Vincetoxicum officinale, a plant of the Asclepias family) as abitter yellow amorphous substance; -- called also asclepiadin, andcynanchin.
The act or process of vitalizing, or infusing the vitalprinciple.

One of the orders of the celestial hierarchy.Thrones, dominations, princedoms, virtues, powers. Milton.Cardinal virtues. See under Cardinal, a.-- In, or By, virtue of, through the force of; by authority of. "Heused to travel through Greece by virtue of this fable, which procuredhim reception in all the towns." Addison. "This they shall attain,partly in virtue of the promise made by God, and partly in virtue ofpiety." Atterbury.-- Theological virtues, the three virtues, faith, hope, and charity.See 1 Cor. xiii. 13.
Any plant of the genus Verbena. Vervain mallow (Bot.), aspecies of mallow (Malva Alcea) with rose-colored flowers.
Excision of a varicosity.
A toxic substance contained in the venom of poisonous snakes;also, a (supposedly identical) toxic substance obtained by thecleavage of an albumose.
The external parts of the female genital organs; sometimes, theopening between the projecting parts of the external organs.

A small air cell, or globular space, in the interior of organiccells, either containing air, or a pellucid watery liquid, or somespecial chemical secretions of the cell protoplasm. Contractilevacuole. (Zoöl.) See under Contractile, and see Illusts. ofInfusoria, and Lobosa.-- Food vacuole. (Zoöl.) See under Food, and see Illust. ofInfusoria.

A turning; a time; -- chiefly used in phrases signifying thatthe part is to be repeated one, two, or more times; as, una volta,once. Seconda volta, second time, points to certain modifications inthe close of a repeated strain.
Having the form or appearance of glass; resembling glass;glasslike.
Producing long, slender twigs or shoots.
A base, C10H19N, produced by heating valeric aldehyde withammonia. It is probably related to the conine alkaloids.
Having the form or appearance of villi; like close-set fibers,either hard or soft; as, the teeth of perch are villiform.

A structure of considerable magnitude, usually with arches orsupported on trestles, for carrying a road, as a railroad, high abovethe ground or water; a bridge; especially, one for crossing a valleyor a gorge. Cf. Trestlework.
Having a voice or vocal quality; having a loud voice or manyvoices; vocal; sounding.Beheld the Iliad and the Odyssey Rise to the swelling of the voicefulsea. Coleridge.
Voluptuousness. [Obs.]
A keeper of stock or cattle; a herdsman. [Southwestern U. S.]Bartlett.
A nest, or habitation, of insects of the wasp kind.
One who writes a volume; an author. [Obs.] Milton.
A liqueur made of white wine, absinthe, and various aromaticdrugs, used to excite the appetite. [Written also vermouth.]
A precious possession; a thing of value, especially a smallthing, as an article of jewelry; -- used mostly in the plural.The food and valuables they offer to the gods. Tylor.
Of or pertaining to the yolk of eggs; as, the vitellinemembrane, a smooth, transparent membrane surrounding the vitellus.
The act of carrying; conveyance; carriage. [Obs.] Bacon.
One of the great divinities of the ancient Romans, identicalwith the Greek Hestia. She was a virgin, and the goddess of thehearth; hence, also, of the fire on it, and the family round it.
The quality or state of being venerable; venerableness. Dr. H.More.
A column of igneous rock formed by congelation of lava in theconduit of a volcano and later exposed by the removal of surroundingrocks.
An inclosure or yard for grapevines; a plantation of vinesproducing grapes.
Pertaining to veins; venous. [R.]
In a variable manner.
The act of variegating or diversifying, or the state of beingdiversified, by different colors; diversity of colors.
A kind of goad or stick with a point of iron. Valet de chambre( Etym: [F.], a body servant, or personal attendant.

Having lost its life and spirit; dead; spiritless; insipid;flat; dull; unanimated; as, vapid beer; a vapid speech; a vapid stateof the blood.A cheap, bloodless reformation, a guiltless liberty, appear flat andvapid to their taste. Burke.-- Vap"id*ly, adv.-- Vap"id*ness, n.
Moving rapidly round a center; vortical. [R.] Cowper.
Cavilous litigation; cavillation. [Obs.] Hudibras.
A rich kind of lace made at Valenciennes, in France. Each pieceis made throughout, ground and pattern, by the same person and withthe same thread, the pattern being worked in the net.
The upper petal of a papilionaceous flower; the standard.
The quality or state of being viscid; also, that which isviscid; glutinous concretion; stickiness.
Being on, or towards, the van, or front. "The vanwardfrontier." De Quincey.
A solemn assertion. [R.]
A genus of shrubs having opposite, petiolate leaves and cymoseflowers, several species of which are cultivated as ornamental, asthe laurestine and the guelder-rose.
A vulgar person; one who has vulgar ideas. Used alsoadjectively.
The salted stomach of a calf, used in making cheese; a rennetbag. [Prov. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to the Valkyrias; hence, relating to battle."Ourself have often tried Valkyrian hymns." Tennyson.
Used in expressing a wish or permission as, volitiveproposition.
Vehicular. Carlyle.
A rare skin disease consisting in the development of smooth,milk-white spots upon various parts of the body.

Belonging to the country of one's birth; one's own by birth ornature; native; indigenous; -- now used chiefly of language; as,English is our vernacular language. "A vernacular disease." Harvey.His skill the vernacular dialect of the Celtic tongue. Fuller.Which in our vernacular idiom may be thus interpreted. Pope.
Destitute of virtue; without efficacy or operating qualities;powerless.Virtueless she wished all herbs and charms. Fairfax.
An avenger. [Obs.] Spenser.
An old French variety of pear, of little value.
Like a vulture; rapacious.
One who, or that which, vanquishes. Milton.
A small instrument with four strings, played with a bow; afiddle.
The goosander. [Local, U. S.]
Covered with vesture or garments; clothed; enveloped.We be vestured with poor cloth. Ld. Berners.
A genus of bats including some of the common smallinsectivorous species of North America and Europe.
To confirm; to render valid; to give legal force to.The chamber of deputies . . . refusing to validate at once theelection of an official candidate. London Spectator.
Having the power of vellicating, plucking, or twitching;causing vellication.
A long, slender, flexible shoot or branch.
To emit vapor; to evaporate. [R.]
Covered with vines.
Of or pertaining to the vagina of the genital canal; as, thevaginal artery.
To perform vivisection upon; to dissect alive. [Colloq.] Pop.Sci. Monthly.
A small vibration. [R.] Chambers.
One of the specialized or tactile hairs which grow about thenostrils, or on other parts of the face, in many animals, as the so-called whiskers of the cat, and the hairs of the nostrils of man.
Of or pertaining to victuals, or provisions; supplyingprovisions; as, a victualing ship.
The quality or state of being verbose; the use of more wordsthan are necessary; prolixity; wordiness; verbiage.The worst fault, by far, is the extreme diffuseness and verbosity ofhis style. Jeffrey.
A carriage. Arbuthnot.
Containing notes by different persons; -- applied to apublication; as, a variorum edition of a book.
Crafty; wily; cunning; artful. [R.]
Having leaves like those of the vine; ornamented with vineleaves. "Vined and figured columns." Sir H. Wotton.
Quality or state of being ventose; windiness; hence, vainglory;pride. Bacon.
Versability. [R.]
A vinedresser. [Obs.]

Having legal strength or force; executed with the properformalities; incapable of being rightfully overthrown or set aside;as, a valid deed; a valid covenant; a valid instrument of any kind; avalid claim or title; a valid marriage.
The art of making roads or ways for traveling, including theconstruction of bridges, canals, viaducts, etc. [R.] R. Park.
A vanessa.
See Vaunt. [Obs.]
A word occurring in the phrase real vellon. See the Note underIts Real.
A salt of vanadic acid. [Formerly also vanadiate.]
Talking idly; boasting; vaunting.-- Va"por*ing*ly, adv.
Velvet. [Obs.] Spenser.
Useful in healing wounds; adapted to the cure of externalinjuries; as, vulnerary plants or potions. "Such vulnerary remedies."Sir W. Scott.-- n. Etym: [Cf. F. vulnéraire.] (Med.)
A combining form used in anatomy to indicate connection with,or relation to, the abdomen; also, connection with, relation to, ordirection toward, the ventral side; as, ventrolateral; ventro-inguinal.

Of or pertaining to a verb; as, a verbal group; deriveddirectly from a verb; as, a verbal noun; used in forming verbs; as, averbal prefix. Verbal inspiration. See under Inspiration.-- Verbal noun (Gram.), a noun derived directly from a verb or verbstem; a verbal. The term is specifically applied to infinitives, andnouns ending in -ing, esp. to the latter. See Gerund, and -ing, 2.See also, Infinitive mood, under Infinitive.
The act of flying; flight. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

Valerianic; specifically, designating any one of threemetameric acids, of which the typical one (called also inactivevaleric acid), C4H9CO2H, is obtained from valerian root and othersources, as a corrosive, mobile, oily liquid, having a strong acidtaste, and an odor of old cheese. Active valeric acid, a metamericvariety which turns the plane of polarization to the right, althoughformed by the oxidation of a levorotatory amyl alcohol.

Uttering or writing censure; containing, or characterized by,abuse; scolding; abusive.-- Vi*tu"per*a*tive*ly, adv.Vituperative appellations derived from their real or supposed illqualities. B. Jonson.
A greenish, oily, nitrogenous hydrocarbon, C12H19N7, obtainedfrom coal tar, and probably consisting of a mixture of severalmetameric compounds which are higher derivatives of the basepyridine.

The state of a villain, or serf; base servitude; tenure oncondition of doing the meanest services for the lord. [In this sensewritten also villenage, and villeinage.]I speak even now as if sin were condemned in a perpetual villanage,never to be manumitted. Milton.Some faint traces of villanage were detected by the curious so lateas the days of the Stuarts. Macaulay.
Covered with verdure; clothed with the fresh green ofvegetation; verdured; verdant; as, verdurous pastures. Milton.
A dyestuff of the induline group, made from aniline, and usedas a substitute for indigo in dyeing wool and silk a violet-blue or agray-blue color.
Venerable from antiquity; ancient; old. [Obs.]
A Spanish measure of length equal to about one yard. The varanow in use equals 33.385 inches. Johnson's Cyc.
A rope to steady the peak of a gaff.
Violating, or tending to violate.

Not in a state of contingency or suspension; fixed; as, vestedrights; vested interests.
