Vested legacy (Law), a legacy the right towhich commences in præsenti, and does not depend on a contingency;as, a legacy to one to be paid when he attains to twenty-one years ofage is a vested legacy, and if the legatee dies before the testator,his representative shall receive it. Blackstone.-- Vested remainder (Law), an estate settled, to remain to adetermined person, after the particular estate is spent. Blackstone.Kent.

Of or pertaining to a vulture; resembling a vulture inqualities or looks; as, the vulturine sea eagle (GypohieraxAngolensis); vulturine rapacity.The vulturine nose, which smells nothing but corruption, is no creditto its possessor. C. Kingsley.
One who holds that vegetables and fruits are the only properfood for man. Strict vegetarians eat no meat, eggs, or milk.
A winged animal; wild fowl; game. [Obs.] Chaucer. Sir T.Browne.
To grow exuberantly; to produce fleshy or warty outgrowths; as,a vegetating papule.
See Otaheite apple.
Face to face.
Of or pertaining to twigs; consisting of twigs; producingtwigs.
Pertaining to, or derived from, vanilla or vanillin; resemblingvanillin; specifically, designating an alcohol and an acidrespectively, vanillin being the intermediate aldehyde.
Beautiful. [R.] E. Waterhouse.
A rampart; a wall, as in a fortification.
The act of putting to death every twentieth man. [R.]
One of the minute papillary processes on certain vascularmembranes; a villosity; as, villi cover the lining of the smallintestines of many animals and serve to increase the absorbingsurface.
Containing or exhibiting positive, or vitreous, electricity.
Having or exercising delegated power; acting by substitution,or in the place of another. Milton.
The person who is vouched, or called into court to support ormake good his warranty of title in the process of common recovery.Blackstone.
To advance; to travel. [Obs.]
Having the nature and qualities of glass; glasslike; --distinguished from ceramic.
Villanage. Blackstone.

Causing dilation or relaxation of the blood vessels; as, thevasodilator nerves, stimulation of which causes dilation of the bloodvessels to which they go. These nerves are also called vaso-inhibitory, and vasohypotonic nerves, since their stimulation causesrelaxation and rest.
The Australian pied crow shrike (Strepera graculina). It isglossy bluish black, with the under tail coverts and the tips andbases of the tail feathers white.

Of or pertaining to the style of Vandyke the painter; used orrepresented by Vandyke. "His Vandyke dress." Macaulay. [Written alsoVandyck.] Vandyke brown (Paint.), a pigment of a deepsemitranssparent brown color, supposed to be the color used byVandyke in his pictures.-- Vandyke collar or cape, a broad collar or cape of linen and lacewith a deep pointed or scalloped edge, worn lying on the shoulders; -- so called from its appearance in pictures by Vandyke.-- Vandyke edge, an edge having ornamental triangular points.
Of or pertaining to the viscera; splanchnic.
Of or pertaining to a vestiary or vestments.

Of or pertaining to volume or volumes. Specifically: --(a) Consisting of many folds, coils, or convolutions.But ended foul in many a scaly fold, Voluminous and vast. Milton.Over which dusky draperies are hanging, and voluminous curtains havelong since fallen. De Quincey.
Of or pertaining to a vortex or vortexes; resembling a vortexin form or motion; whirling; as, a vortical motion.-- Vor"ti*cal*ly, adv.
Turn, that is, turn over the leaf. Volti subito Etym: [It.](Mus.), turn over quickly.

A space entirely devoid of matter (called also, by way ofdistinction, absolute vacuum); hence, in a more general sense, aspace, as the interior of a closed vessel, which has been exhaustedto a high or the highest degree by an air pump or other artificialmeans; as, water boils at a reduced temperature in a vacuum.
An inferior kind of vanilla, the pods of Vanilla Pompona.
To reënlist for service as a soldier. [U.S.] Gen. W. T.Sherman.
Verecund. [Obs.] "Verecundious generosity." Sir H. Wotton.
One of the substances of which vegetable tissue is composed,differing from cellulose in its solubility in certain media.
A waste region; boundless space; immensity. "The watery vast."Pope.Michael bid sound The archangel trumpet. Through the vast of heavenIt sounded. Milton.
Same as Visitatorial.
A common gray European moth (Halia vauaria) having a V-shapedspot of dark brown on each of the fore wings.

A process for coating metal (usually iron or steel) surfaceswith zinc by exposing them to the vapor of zinc instead of, as inordinary galvanizing, to molten zinc; -- called also Sherardizing.Vapor galvanizing is accomplished by heating the articles to begalvanized together with zinc dust in an air tight receptacle to atemperature of about 600º F., which is 188º below the melting pointof zinc, or by exposing the articles to vapor from molten zinc in aseparate receptacle, using hydrogen or other reducing gas to preventoxidation.

A mineral water found at Vichy, France. It is essentially aneffervescent solution of sodium, calcium, and magnetism carbonates,with sodium and potassium chlorides; also, by extension, anyartificial or natural water resembling in composition the Vichy waterproper. Called also, colloquially, Vichy.
A kind of woven fabric for waistcoats, having the weft of wooland the warp of silk or cotton. [Written also valentia.]
Same as Veil.
Of or pertaining to the reign of Queen Victoria of England; as,the Victorian poets. Victorian period. See Dionysian period, underDyonysian.
An explosive containing nitroglycerin. It is used in blasting.
Inclined to fluctuate; wavering. Tennyson.-- Vac"il*la`ting*ly, adv.
One who visits; a guest; a visitor.When the visitant comes again, he is no more a stranger. South.
To find fault with; to scold; to overwhelm with wordy abuse; tocensure severely or abusively; to rate.
Turned round; giddy. [R.] Coleridge.
A quality analogous to that of a viscous fluid, supposed to becaused by internal friction, especially in the case of gases.

Abandoned; having no heir, possessor, claimant, or occupier;as, a vacant estate. Bouvier. Vacant succession (Law), one that isclaimed by no person, or where all the heirs are unknown, or whereall the known heirs to it have renounced it. Burrill.
Flourishing, as in spring; vernal. [Obs.] "Vernant flowers."Milton.
The use of vowels. [R.]
A writer of verses; especially, a writer of commonplace poetry;a poetaster; a rhymer; -- used humorously or in contempt.
The hypothetical radical characteristic of vanillic alcohol.

Either one of two or more species of South American blood-sucking bats belonging to the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. Thesebats are destitute of molar teeth, but have strong, sharp cuttingincisors with which they make punctured wounds from which they suckthe blood of horses, cattle, and other animals, as well as man,chiefly during sleep. They have a cæcal appendage to the stomach, inwhich the blood with which they gorge themselves is stored.

The power possessed by living organisms, both animal andvegetable, of adapting themselves to modifications or changes intheir environment, thus possibly giving rise to ultimate variation ofstructure or function.
The quality or state of being vague.
Cowpox; vaccina. See Cowpox.
A verse. [Obs.] Milton.
A small hole, as the stop in a flute; a vent. Shak.

A bladder. Vesica piscis. Etym: [L., dish bladder.] (Eccl. Art)A glory, or aureole, of oval shape, or composed of two arcs ofcircles usually represented as surrounding a divine personage. Morerarely, an oval composed of two arcs not representing a glory; asolid oval, etc.
See Virgo.

A road way. Via Lactea Etym: [L.] (Anat.), the Milky Way, orGalaxy. See Galaxy, 1.-- Via media Etym: [L.] (Theol.), the middle way; -- a name appliedto their own position by the Anglican high-churchmen, as beingbetween the Roman Catholic Church and what they term extremeProtestantism.
A tribe of spiders, comprising some of those which take theirprey in a web, but which also frequently run with agility, and chaseand seize their prey.
To raise little bladders or blisters upon; to inflame andseparate the cuticle of; to blister. Wiseman.
An instrument for measuring the degree of viscosity of liquids,as solutions of gum.
A player on the violin.
An assailant. [Obs.] Dr. H. More.
Velvet. [Obs.] "A woman's crupper of velure." Shak.
See Vinaigrette, n., 2.
The quality or state of being vincible.
The quality or state of being visible.
One who, or that which, vulcanizes; esp., an apparatus forvulcanizing caoutchouc.
Rashful; modest. [Obs.]
Resembling vermin; in the manner of vermin. [Obs.] Gauden.

A piece of strong steel wire with the ends curved and pointed,used on toe or quarter cracks to bind the edges together and preventmotion. It is clasped into two notches, one on each side of thecrack, burned into the wall with a cautery iron.
The worship of Vishnu.
The person to whom a thing is vended, or sold; -- thecorrelative of vendor.

One who pronounces a valedictory address; especially, inAmerican colleges, the student who pronounces the valedictory of thegraduating class at the annual commencement, usually the student whoranks first in scholarship.

A little verse; especially, a short verse or text said or sungin public worship by the priest or minister, and followed by aresponse from the people.The psalms were in number fifteen, . . . being digested intoversicles. Strype.

Acquainted or familiar, as the result of experience, study,practice, etc.; skilled; practiced.Deep versed in books and shallow in himself. Milton.Opinions . . . derived from studying the Scriptures, wherein he wasversed beyond any person of his age. Southey.These men were versed in the details of business. Macaulay.
Able or tending to vivify, animate, or give life; vivifying.

The skin of the squirrel, much used in the fourteenth centuryas fur for garments, and frequently mentioned by writers of thatperiod in describing the costly dresses of kings, nobles, andprelates. It is represented in heraldry by a series of small shieldsplaced close together, and alternately white and blue. Fairholt.No vair or ermine decked his garment. Sir W. Scott.Counter vair (Her.), a fur resembling vair, except in the arrangementof the patches or figures.
Tending to a violet color; violascent.
Resembling vellum.
A votary.Like a sad votarist in palmer's weed. Milton.
A religious and philanthropic organization, similar to theSalvation Army, founded (1896) by Commander and Mrs. BallingtonBooth.
A singer, or vocal musician, as opposed to an instrumentalist.
A vertebra. [Obs.]
A mask; a visor. [Archaic] "A grotesque vizard." Sir W. Scott.To mislead and betray them under the vizard of law. Milton.
Apt or fit to fly. [R.]
A traveler; -- applied in Canada to a man employed by the furcompanies in transporting goods by the rivers and across the land, toand from the remote stations in the Northwest.
A machine for cleaning carpets, tapestry, upholstered work,etc., by suction.
The science which treats of phenomena due to plutonic action,as in volcanoes, hot springs, etc. [R.]
To deprive of the viscera, or entrails; to eviscerate; todisembowel.
A salt of veratric acid.
An ichneumon (Herpestes galera) native of Southern Africa andMadagascar. It is reddish brown or dark brown, grizzled with white.Called also vondsira, and marsh ichneumon.
To breed vermin.
Of or pertaining to voodooism, or a voodoo; as, voodooincantations.

A stringed musical instrument formerly in use, of the same formas the violin, but larger, and having six strings, to be struck witha bow, and the neck furnished with frets for stopping the strings.Me softer airs befit, and softer strings Of lute, or viol still, moreapt for mournful things. Milton.

An American thrush (Turdus fuscescens) common in the NorthernUnited States and Canada. It is light tawny brown above. The breastis pale buff, thickly spotted with brown. Called also Wilson'sthrush.Sometimes I hear the veery's clarion. Thoreau.
Resembling smallpox; pertaining to the disease calledvarioloid.
The act of volcanizing, or the state of being volcanized; theprocess of undergoing volcanic heat, and being affected by it.
Bearing or containing vittæ.
The act of vending, or selling; sale.
Against; as, John Doe versus Richard Roe; -- chiefly used inlegal language, and abbreviated to v. or vs.
A trade name for a brown dyestuff obtained from certain basicazo compounds of benzene; -- called also Bismarck brown, Manchesterbrown, etc.
Any substance in the gaseous, or aëriform, state, the conditionof which is ordinarily that of a liquid or solid.
A person appointed to inspect highways, fences, or the like,and to report upon the same.
Like a vixen; vixenish. Barrow.
Villainy. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who vilifies or defames.
A condition in which the circulation is retarded, and theentire mass of blood is less oxygenated than it normally is.
Feeling or indicating vainglory; elated by vanity; boastful."Arrogant and vainglorious expression." Sir M. Hale.-- Vain`glo"ri*ous*ly, adv.-- Vain`glo"ri*ous*ness, n.
Pertaining both to the abdomen and groin, or to the abdomen andinguinal canal; as, ventro-inguinal hernia.
A cumbrous two-wheeled pleasure carriage used in Cuba.

A genus of minute, pale-green, globular, organisms, about onefiftieth of an inch in diameter, found rolling through water, themotion being produced by minute colorless cilia. It has beenconsidered as belonging to the flagellate Infusoria, but is nowreferred to the vegetable kingdom, and each globule is considered acolony of many individuals. The commonest species is Volvox globator,often called globe animalcule.
Wearing a vizard. [R.] Shak.
An outer, or exterior. wall. See Vauntmure. [Obs.] Hakluyt.
To gather the vintage. [Obs.] Evelyn.
To give the quality, sound, or office of a vowel to.
The act or power of vomiting. Grew.
Devoted to the offices of Venus, or love; venereal. [Obs.] "Iam all venerean in feeling." Chaucer.
Highly regarded; esteemed; prized; as, a valued contributor; avalued friend. Valued policy. See under Policy.
In a viviparous manner.

Of or pertaining to a worm or worms; resembling a worm; shapedlike a worm; especially, resembling the motion or track of a worm;as, the vermicular, or peristaltic, motion of the intestines. SeePeristaltic. "A twisted form vermicular." Cowper.

Causing movement in the walls of vessels; as, the vasomotormechanisms; the vasomotor nerves, a system of nerves distributed overthe muscular coats of the blood vessels. Vasomotor center, the chiefdominating or general center which supplies all the unstriped musclesof the arterial system with motor nerves, situated in a part of themedulla oblongata; a center of reflex action by the working of whichafferent impulses are changed into efferent, -- vasomotor impulsesleading either to dilation or constriction of the blood vessels.

Of, pertaining to, or situated near, the belly, or ventralside, of an animal or of one of its parts; hemal; abdominal; as, theventral fin of a fish; the ventral root of a spinal nerve; -- opposedto Ant: dorsal.
See Varvel.
Furnished or clothed with villi.
One who vaticinates; a prophet.
The thirteenth, or intercalary, month of the Jewishecclesiastical calendar, which is added about every third year.
One of a picked company of irregular riflemen in each regimentof the French infantry.
A variety; -- used in giving scientific names, and oftenabbreviated to var.
The cultivation of the vine, esp. for making wine; viticulture.
Veneficial. [Obs.] "Venefical instruments." B. Jonson.
The act of vanquishing, or the state of being vanquished. Bp.Hall.
To convert into glass; to vitrify. [Obs.] Bacon.
See Brucine.
A scaly granular variety of anhydrite of a grayish white color,used for ornamental purposes.
Of or pertaining to a rampart. Vallar crown (Rom. Antiq.), acircular gold crown with palisades, bestowed upon the soldier whofirst surmounted the rampart and broke into the enemy's camp.
A vexillum.
A bond or pledge for appearance before a judge on a certainday. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to Saint Vincent de Paul, or founded by him.[R.]
Vectitation. [Obs.]
The contents or substance of the ovum; egg yolk. See Illust. ofOvum.
The evening star; Hesper; Venus, when seen after sunset; hence,the evening. Shak.
Ventriloquism.

A spiral scroll which forms the chief feature of the Ioniccapital, and which, on a much smaller scale, is a feature in theCorinthian and Composite capitals. See Illust. of Capital, alsoHelix, and Stale.

A degraded form of superstition and sorcery, said to includehuman sacrifices and cannibalism in some of its rites. It isprevalent among the negroes of Hayti, and to some extent in theUnited States, and is regarded as a relic of African barbarism.
Veratrine.
The quality or state of being variable; variability. James i.17.
A viameter.

Any one of numerous species of long, slender Alcyonariabelonging to Virgularia and allied genera of the family Virgularidæ.These corals are allied to the sea-pens, but have a long rodlikerhachis inclosing a slender, round or square, calcareous axis. Thepolyps are arranged in transverse rows or clusters along each side ofthe rhachis.
Vinous.

A view; especially, a view through or between interveningobjects, as trees; a view or prospect through an avenue, or the like;hence, the trees or other objects that form the avenue.The finished garden to the view Its vistas opens, and its alleysgreen. Thomson.In the groves of their academy, at the end of every vista, you seenothing but the gallows. Burke.The shattered tower which now forms a vista from his window. Sir W.Scott.

Of or pertaining to the higher division of plants, that is, thephænogamous plants, all of which are vascular, in distinction fromthe cryptogams, which to a large extent are cellular only. Vascularplants (Bot.), plants composed in part of vascular tissue, as allflowering plants and the higher cryptogamous plants, or those of theclass Pteridophyta. Cf. Cellular plants, Cellular.-- Vascular system (Bot.), the body of associated ducts and woodyfiber; the fibrovascular part of plants.-- Vascular tissue (Bot.), vegetable tissue composed partly ofducts, or sap tubes.-- Water vascular system (Zoöl.), a system of vessels in annelids,nemerteans, and many other invertebrates, containing a circulatingfluid analogous to blood, but not of the same composition. Inannelids the fluid which they contain is usually red, but in some itis green, in others yellow, or whitish.
To convert into, or cause to resemble, glass or a glassysubstance, by heat and fusion.
Causing vomiting; emetic; vomitive.

The place or places adjoining or near; neighborhood; vicinity;as, a jury must be of the vicinage. "To summon the Protestantgentleman of the vicinage." Macaulay.Civil war had broken up all the usual ties of vicinage and goodneighborhood. Sir W. Scott.
To wit; namely; -- often abbreviated to viz.

Having the nature, properties, or qualities, of an adult man;characteristic of developed manhood; hence, masterful; forceful;specifically, capable of begetting; -- opposed to womanly, feminine,and puerile; as, virile age, virile power, virile organs.
Something which differs in form from another thing, thoughreally the same; as, a variant from a type in natural history; avariant of a story or a word.
See Villain, 1.
Same as Vitrifaction. Sir T. Browne. Ure.
A ring surrounding a bugle or hunting horn.
A genus of plants including all true grapevines.
A rampart or intrenchment.
See Wends.
A genus of herbaceous plants of which several species areextensively cultivated for the great beauty of their flowers;vervain.
A curtain of light and translucent material intended to besecured directly to the woodwork of a French casement window or aglazed door.
Serving to in invest, or sheathe; sheathing. Vaginant leaf(Bot.), a leaf investing the stem or branch by its base, which hasthe form of a tube.
Vileness; baseness. [Obs.] Kennet.
Manner of supporting or continuing life or vegetation. [Obs.]Sir T. Browne.

A small bottle, usually of glass; a little glass vessel with anarrow aperture intended to be closed with a stopper; as, a vial ofmedicine. [Written also phial.]Take thou this vial, being then in bed, And this distilled liquorthou off. Shak.
Inclined to venture; not loth to run risk or danger; venturous;bold; daring; adventurous; as, a venturesome boy or act.-- Ven"ture*some*ly, adv.-- Ven"ture*some*ness, n.
A vocal sound; specifically, a purely vocal element of speech,unmodified except by resonance; a vowel or a diphthong; a tonicelement; a tonic; -- distinguished from a subvocal, and a nonvocal.

A disagreement or difference between two parts of the samelegal proceeding, which, to be effectual, ought to agree, -- asbetween the writ and the declaration, or between the allegation andthe proof. Bouvier. A variance, in disagreement; in a state ofdissension or controversy; at enmity. "What cause brought him so soonat variance with himself" Milton.
A vanishing. [Obs.]
The hypothetical radical C5H9O, regarded as the essentialnucleus of certain valeric acid derivatives.
An allowance for traveling expenses made to those who were sentinto the provinces to exercise any office or perform any service.

The quality or state of being venal, or purchasable;mercenariness; prostitution of talents, offices, or services, formoney or reward; as, the venality of a corrupt court; the venality ofan official.Complaints of Roman venality became louder. Milton.
Excitement of imagination such as animates a poet, artist, ormusician, in composing or performing; rapture; enthusiasm; spirit;energy.
Wearing a visor; masked.Visored falsehood and base forgery. Milton.
Viciousness; depravity.The perverseness and vitiosity of man's will. South.
See Vitriolic. [Obs.]
The qualities or characteristics of a virago.
The monitor. See Monitor, 3.
To endow with life, or vitality; to give life to; to makealive; as, vitalized blood.

Green; greenness; freshness of vegetation; as, the verdure ofthe meadows in June.A wide expanse of living verdure, cultivated gardens, shady groves,fertile cornfields, flowed round it like a sea. Motley.

Of or pertaining to Valsalva, an Italian anatomist of the 17thcentury. Valsalvian experiment (Med.), the process of inflating themiddle ear by closing the mouth and nostrils, and blowing so as topuff out the cheeks.
The doctrine that all the functions of a living organism aredue to an unknown vital principle distinct from all chemical andphysical forces.
Volatilizable. [Obs.]
Being of no value; having no worth.
An old rustic dance, accompanied with singing.
A policy in which the value of the goods, property, or interestinsured is specified; -- opposed to open policy.
The appearance of truth; verisimilitude.
Changed; altered; various; diversified; as, a variedexperience; varied interests; varied scenery.-- Va"ried*ly, adv.The varied fields of science, ever new. Cowper.
A Russian measure of length containing 3,500 English feet.[Written also werst.]
See Point, n., 26.
Cloth for vests; a vest pattern.
The common sort of people; the crowd; the mob. [Obs.] Fuller.
A law requiring insurance companies to pay to the insured, incase of total loss, the full amount of the insurance, regardless ofthe actual value of the property at the time of the loss.
Viceroyalty.
One who cultivates a vineyard.
An artificial division of vertebrates including those thatproduce their young alive; -- opposed to Ovipara.
A vesicatory.
Made of velvet; soft and delicate, like velvet; velvety. " Thecowslip's velvet head." Milton.

The god of the waters; the Indian Neptune. He is regarded asregent of the west, and lord of punishment, and is represented asriding on a sea monster, holding in his hand a snaky cord or noosewith which to bind offenders, under water.
One of the oil tubes in the fruit of umbelliferous plants.

An albuminous body, belonging to the class of globulins,obtained from yolk of egg, of which it is the chief proteidconstituent, and from the seeds of many plants. From the latter itcan be separated in crystalline form.
The quality of being valuable.

Capable of being overcome or subdued; conquerable. "He, notvincible in spirit . . . drew his sword." Hayward. "Vincible by humanaid." Paley. Vincible ignorance (Theol.), ignorance within theindividual's control and for which, therefore, he is responsiblebefore God.
In a vigilant manner.
A fogged plate.
The quality or state of being volcanic, or volcanic origin;volcanicity. [R.]
Of or pertaining to a vintage, or grape harvest. [R.]
An instrument for measuring the volumes of gases or liquids byintroducing them into a vessel of known capacity.
The formation of varices; varicosity.
Food for human beings, esp. when it is cooked or prepared forthe table; that which supports human life; provisions; sustenance;meat; viands.Then had we plenty of victuals. Jer. xliv. 17.
The kestrel. [Prov. Eng.]
Of or pertaining to vitriol; derived from, or resembling,vitriol; vitriolous; as, a vitriolic taste. Cf. Vitriol. Vitriolicacid (Old Chem.), (a) sulphuric acid. See Vitriol (b). [Colloq.]
Any larval gastropod or bivalve mollusk in the state when it isfurnished with one or two ciliated membranes for swimming.
A cheap claret, used as a table wine in France.
One who votes; one who has a legal right to vote, or give hissuffrage; an elector; a suffragist; as, as, an independent voter.
Variolous.
Striped; streaked. [Obs.]
The mink.
Any small leguminous plant of the genus Lathyrus, especially L.Nissolia.
Brisk; vivacious; with spirit; -- a direction to perform apassage in a brisk and lively manner.

A fine kind of parchment, usually made from calfskin, andrendered clear and white, -- used as for writing upon, and forbinding books. Vellum cloth, a fine kind of cotton fabric, made verytransparent, and used as a tracing cloth.
A versifier. [R.] "The best versificator next Virgil." Dryden.
A mineral occurring in yellowish, and ruby-red hexagonalcrystals. It consist of lead vanadate with a small proportion of leadchloride.

Dizziness or swimming of the head; an affection of the head inwhich objects, though stationary, appear to move in variousdirections, and the person affected finds it difficult to maintain anerect posture; giddiness. Quian.

The act of a naval commander who visits, or enters on board, avessel belonging to another nation, for the purpose of ascertainingher character and object, but without claiming or exercising a rightof searching the vessel. It is, however, usually coupled with theright of search (see under Search), visitation being used for thepurpose of search.
A member of a vestry; especially (Prot. Epis. Ch.), a memberother than a warden. See Vestry.
In a vacant manner; inanely.
Living through the winter, or from year to year; perennial.[R.]
To make visual, or visible; to see in fancy. [Written alsovisualise.]No one who has not seen them [glaciers] can possibly visualize them.Lubbock.
Full of, or subject to, changes.
The quality of being voracious; voraciousness.
Of or pertaining to the vagus, or pneumogastric nerves;pneumogastric.
To convert into a verb; to verbify.

Abounding in words; using or containing more words than arenecessary; tedious by a multiplicity of words; prolix; wordy; as, averbose speaker; a verbose argument.Too verbose in their way of speaking. Ayliffe.-- Ver*bose"ly, adv.-- Ver*bose"ness, n.

Producing young in a living state, as most mammals, or as thoseplants the offspring of which are produced alive, either by bulbsinstead of seeds, or by the seeds themselves germinating on theplant, instead of falling, as they usually do; -- opposed tooviparous. Viviparous fish. (Zoöl.) See Embiotocoid.-- Viviparous shell (Zoöl.), any one of numerous species ofoperculated fresh-water gastropods belonging to Viviparus, Melantho,and allied genera. Their young, when born, have a well-developedspiral shell.
a. & n. from Vote, v. Voting paper, a form of ballot containingthe names of more candidates than there are offices to be filled, thevoter making a mark against the preferred names. [Eng.]
In a valid manner; so as to be valid.
The quality or state of being like a vulture; rapaciousness.
A voice. Vox humana ( Etym: [L., human voice] (Mus.), a reedstop in an organ, made to imitate the human voice.
To prohibit; to negative; also, to refuse assent to, as alegislative bill, and thus prevent its enactment; as, to veto anappropriation bill.
The theory or practice of living upon vegetables and fruits.
Having the surface covered with a fine and dense silkypubescence; velvety; as, a velutinous leaf.
See Durukuli.
To embellish; to change fancifully; to present under newaspects, as of form, key, measure, etc. See Variation, 4.
Pledge; security; bail. See Mortgage. Vadium vivum Etym: [LL.](Law), a living pledge, which exists where an estate is granted untila debt is paid out of its proceeds.
Like a cleft with projecting edges.
Formed like a vase, or like a common flowerpot.
Onset; rush; violent draught or wind. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who makes or favors a version; a translator. [R.]
An organ stop of delicate stringlike quality, having for eachfinger key a pair of pipes, of which one is tuned slightly sharp togive a wavy effect to their joint tone.
A vaccinator.
Of or pertaining to a villein.
Acting as a substitute; -- said of abnormal action whichreplaces a suppressed normal function; as, vicarious hemorrhagereplacing menstruation.
The act or process of vaporizing, or the state of beingconverted into vapor; the artificial formation of vapor;specifically, the conversion of water into steam, as in a steamboiler.
, pl. of Villus.
A wardrobe; a robing room; a vestry. Fuller.
See Meson.
Vitrifiable. [Obs.]
Virtuous; powerful. [Obs.] Spenser.
Fault; defect; coarseness. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The dissection of an animal while alive, for the purpose ofmaking physiological investigations.
Villages; a district of villages. [Obs.] "The maidens of thevillagery." Shak.
The quality or state of being vapid; vapidness.
To a vast extent or degree; very greatly; immensely. Jer.Taylor.
Provisions; victuals. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]I 'll join you at three, if the vivers can tarry so long. Sir W.Scott.
Shifting.-- Veer"ing*ly, adv.
Scoffing; scurrilous. [A Latinism. Obs.] "Subject to thepetulancy of every vernaculous orator." B. Jonson.
At or within a vertebra or vertebræ; -- distinguished frominterverterbrally.

One who enters into service voluntarily, but who, when inservice, is subject to discipline and regulations like othersoldiers; -- opposed to conscript; specifically, a voluntary memberof the organized militia of a country as distinguished from thestanding army.

Near; vicine. T. Warton. Vicinal planes (Min.), subordinateplanes on a crystal, which are very near to the fundamental planes inangles, and sometimes take their place. They have in general verycomplex symbols.
The quality or state of being vitreous; glassiness, or thequality of being vitrescent; capability of conversion into glass;susceptibility of being formed into glass. Kirwan.
To make void, or empty. [R.]
Tending, or having power, to raise a blister.-- n.
Of, pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitroso derivativeof barbituric acid. It is obtained as a white or yellow crystallinesubstance, and forms characteristic yellow, blue, and violet salts.
A genus of Carnivora including the foxes.
A covering for a person or thing; as, a nun's veil; a patenveil; an altar veil.

One belonging to the pirate crews from among the Northmen, whoplundered the coasts of Europe in the eighth, ninth, and tenthcenturies.Of grim Vikings, and the rapture Of the sea fight, and the capture,And the life of slavery. Longfellow.
A genus of marine green algæ, in which the whole frond consistsof a single oval or cylindrical cell, often an inch in length.
Infirm; sickly; valetudinarian.-- Val`e*tu"di*na*ri*ness, n.It renders the habit of society dangerously. Burke.
The ancient sacred literature of the Hindoos; also, one of thefour collections, called Rig-Veda, Yajur-Veda, Sama-Veda, andAtharva-Veda, constituting the most ancient portions of thatliterature.
The act of wounding, or the state of being wounded. [Obs.]

Uttered with voice; pronounced with vibrations of the vocalcords; sonant; -- said of a sound uttered with the glottis narrowed.Voiced stop, Voice stop (Phon.), a stopped consonant made with tonefrom the larynx while the mouth organs are closed at some point; asonant mute, as b, d, g hard.
A certain function relating to a system of forces and theirpoints of application, -- first used by Clausius in the investigationof problems in molecular physics.
Somewhat distended in the middle; ventricular.
See Verger. [Obs.]
A salt of vanillic acid.
A comma. [R.]In the MSS. of Chaucer, the line is always broken by a cæsura in themiddle, which is pointed by a virgule. Hallam.
The hypothetical radical C2H3, regarded as the characteristicresidue of ethylene and that related series of unsaturatedhydrocarbons with which the allyl compounds are homologous.
In a violent manner.
One who treats of vermes, or worms; a helminthologist.

A ring-shaped mass of moving fluid which, by virtue of itsmotion of rotation around an axis disposed in circular form, attainsa more or less distinct separation from the surrounding medium andhas many of the properties of a solid.
A cow house, dairy house, or cow pasture. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]Wright.
An article of food; provisions; food; victuals; -- used chieflyin the plural. Cowper.Viands of various kinds allure the taste. Pope.
A prediction; a vaticination. [Obs.] Holinshed.
One who, or that which, vaporizes, or converts into vapor.
Of or pertaining to verses; designating distinct divisions of awriting.
A vivisectionist.
Vitelline.
To make a victim of, esp. by deception; to dupe; to cheat.
Green. [Obs.]The virid marjoram Her sparkling beauty did but see. Crompton.
A female vassal. [R.] Spenser.
Full of vapor; vaporous.
Any of several fruit flies, esp. Drosophila ampelopophila,which breed in imperfectly sealed preserves and in pickles.
A uneven, permanent dilatation of a vein.
The state of containing vesicles, or the process by whichvesicles are formed.
The bush hog, or boshvark.
One who, or that which, vaccinates.
An avant-courier. See Van-courier. [Obs.] Holland.
Having long and slender trailing stems.
Vigorous; lively; active; vegete. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
The quality or state of being vegetal, or exhibiting thosephysiological phenomena which are common to plants and animals. SeeVegetal, a., 2.
See Villainy.
A vessel for holding holy water.
Of or pertaining to viticulture.
The act or process of imparting to caoutchouc, gutta-percha, orthe like, greater elasticity, durability, or hardness by heating withsulphur under pressure.
Pertaining both to the vulva and the vagina.

To diversify in external appearance; to mark with differentcolors; to dapple; to streak; as, to variegate a floor with marble ofdifferent colors.The shells are filled with a white spar, which variegates and adds tothe beauty of the stone. Woodward.
Flying with sails; passing under full sail. [R.]
Quality or state of being vertical.
The quality or state of being versable. [R.] Sterne
A yellow pigment consisting of a compound of vanadium.
A touchhole; a vent.
A volcanist.
To make vile; to debase; to degrade; to revile. [R.]Were virtue by descent, a noble name Could never villanize hisfather's fame. Dryden.
The state of widows or of widowhood; also, widows,collectively.
One of the West Goths. See the Note under Goth.-- Vis`i*goth"ic, a.
To caper or frolic. [Obs.]
Resection or excision of the vas deferens.
In various or different ways.
Of or pertaining to twenty; consisting of twenty.
Covered with verdure. Poe.
To make a victim of; to sacrifice; to immolate. [Obs.]Bullokar.

Capable of turning; freely movable; as, a versatile anther,which is fixed at one point to the filament, and hence is very easilyturned around; a versatile toe of a bird.-- Ver"sa*tile*ly, adv.-- -- Ver"sa*tile*ness, n.
To clothe with possession; as, to vest a person with an estate;also, to give a person an immediate fixed right of present or futureenjoyment of; as, an estate is vested in possession. Bouvier.
Virginity; maidenhood.
Exercising the will; acting from choice; willing, or havingpower to will. "What I do, I do volitient, not obedient." Mrs.Browning.

The mark of the foot left on the earth; a track or footstep; atrace; a sign; hence, a faint mark or visible sign left by somethingwhich is lost, or has perished, or is no longer present; remains; as,the vestiges of ancient magnificence in Palmyra; vestiges of formerpopulation.What vestiges of liberty or property have they left Burke.Ridicule has followed the vestiges of Truth, but never usurped herplace. Landor.
A medicine which destroys intestinal worms; a worm killer.Pereira.

Of or pertaining to visitation, or a judicial visitor orsuperintendent; visitorial.An archdeacon has visitatorial power. Ayliffe.The queen, however, still had over the church a visitatorial power ofvast and undefined extent. Macaulay.

Any one of many species of marine gastropods belonging toVermetus and allied genera, of the family Vermetidæ. Their shells areregularly spiral when young, but later in life the whorls becomeseparate, and the shell is often irregularly bent and contorted likea worm tube.
A vista; a prospect. [R.] Gay.Through the long visto of a thousand years. Young.
A European lake whitefish (Coregonus Willughbii, or C.Vandesius) native of certain lakes in Scotland and England. It isregarded as a delicate food fish. Called also vendis.
See Vizier.
A kind of Venetian glass or glassware in which white threadsare embedded in transparent glass with a lacelike or netlike effect.
That part of a helmet which is intended for the admission ofair, -- sometimes in the visor. Spenser.Her ventail up so high that he descried Her goodly visage and herbeauty's pride. Fairfax.
Of or pertaining to a vestige or remnant; like a vestige.

One of a system of ordnance, including machine, quick-fire,coast, and field guns, of all calibers, manufactured by the combinedfirms of Vickers' Sons of Sheffield and Maxim of Birmingham andelsewhere, England.
One who gathers the vintage.
An endemic disease occurring in the Andes in Peru,characterized by warty tumors which ulcerate and bleed. It isprobably due to a special bacillus, and is often fatal.
A word; a term; a name; specifically, a word considered ascomposed of certain sounds or letters, without regard to its meaning.Swamped near to drowning in a tide of ingenious vocables. Carlyle.
To make efficacious; to give virtue of efficacy. [Obs.] Harvey.

Amount, fullness, quantity, or caliber of voice or tone. Atomicvolume, Molecular volume (Chem.), the ratio of the atomic andmolecular weights divided respectively by the specific gravity of thesubstance in question.-- Specific volume (Physics & Chem.), the quotient obtained bydividing unity by the specific gravity; the reciprocal of thespecific gravity. It is equal (when the specific gravity is referredto water at 4º C. as a standard) to the number of cubic centimetersoccupied by one gram of the substance.
See Ventouse. [Obs.]
Madeira mahogany; the coarse, dark-colored wood of the PerseaIndica.
Any one of numerous species of large, handsome marinegastropods belonging to Voluta and allied genera.
The quality or state of being vivid; vividness. [R.]
An apparatus for measuring speed, as of machinery or vessels,but especially of projectiles.
As much as a vessel will hold; enough to fill a vessel.
Having wounds; vulnerose. [R.]
A popular song, or national air.
See Voodoo.
To contend in law litigiously or cavilously. [Obs.]
Varnish. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An axis; hinge; a turning point. E. Waterhouse.
Having a veil; veiled.
Discharged with a sudden burst, or as if in a volley; as,volleyed thunder.
Of or pertaining to roads; happening on roads. [Obs.]
A genus of Infusoria which form minute vaselike or tubularcases in which they dwell.
An arrow or bolt for a crossbow having feathers or brass placedat an angle with the shaft to make it spin in flying.
Of or pertaining to a natural order of plants, of which theviolet is the type. It contains about twenty genera and two hundredand fifty species.
Charged with vair; variegated with shield-shaped figures. SeeVair.
Drunkennes. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to a ventricle; bellied.
One who vents; one who utters, reports, or publishes. [R.]Barrow.
Changed into a vitriol or a sulphate, or subjected to theaction of sulphuric acid or of a sulphate; as, vitriolated potash, i.e., potassium sulphate.
A game in word making. See Logomachy, 2.
Capable of living; born alive and with such form anddevelopment of organs as to be capable of living; -- said of anewborn, or a prematurely born, infant.
A parochial assembly; an assembly of persons who manageparochial affairs; -- so called because usually held in a vestry.
By word of mouth; orally.
A glass show case for displaying fine wares, specimens, etc.
An instrument for measuring in volts the differences ofpotential between different points of an electrical circuit.
A divinity of the modern Hindoo trimurti, or trinity. He isregarded as the preserver, while Brahma is the creator, and Siva thedestroyer of the creation.
Of or pertaining to the vomer.
A magnificent assemblage of buildings at Rome, near the churchof St. Peter, including the pope's palace, a museum, a library, afamous chapel, etc.
A genus of parasitic shrubs, including the mistletoe of Europe.
A gland secreting the yolk of the eggs in trematodes,turbellarians, and some other helminths.
The quality or state of being void;
One of the organs, as the brain, heart, or stomach, in thegreat cavities of the body of an animal; -- especially used in theplural, and applied to the organs contained in the abdomen.
Ventriloquous.
A turning point; the principal or highest point; top; summit;crown; apex. Specifically: --(a) (Anat.)
Of or pertaining to the framework, or skeleton, or skeleton, ofthe viscera; as, the visceroskeletal system of muscles. Mivart.
Shaped like a wart or warts.
One who vindicates; one who justifies or maintains. Locke.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and the uterus.
The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerableness.
Vitiosity. [R.]
A varicose enlargement of the veins of the spermatic cord;also, a like enlargement of the veins of the scrotum.
A ventouse. [Obs.] Holland.
A verse or verses. See Verse. [Obs.] "Ten vers or twelve."Chaucer.
A bout; a thrust; a venew. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.Three veneys for a dish of stewed prunes. Shak.
Chicken pox.

To condescend; to deign; to yield; to descend or stoop.Chaucer.Vouchsafe, O Lord, to keep us this day without sin. Bk. of Com.Prayer.Vouchsafe, illustrious Ormond, to behold What power the charms ofbeauty had of old. Dryden.
A deal at cards that draws all the tricks. Swift.
Of or pertaining to a calf or veal.
One who deals in wine; a wine seller, or wine merchant.
The veltfare. [Prov. Eng.]
Vehicular.
To inoculate with the cowpox by means of a virus, calledvaccine, taken either directly or indirectly from cows.
Having elytra; sheath-winged. [R.]
A kind of clamp with gimlet points for holding a barrel headwhile the staves are being closed around it. Knight.
An instrument to observe and record vibrations.
The quality or state of being verbal; mere words; bare literalexpression. [R.] "More verbality than matter." Bp. Hall.
Vortical; whirling; as, a vorticose motion.
Intended for the treatment of varicose veins; -- said ofelastic stockings, bandages. and the like.

A volatile liquid hydrocarbon, C5H6, related to ethylene andacetylene, but possessing the property of unsaturation in the thirddegree. It is the only known member of a distinct series ofcompounds. It has a garlic odor.
An ancient Latin version of the Scripture, and the only versionwhich the Roman Church admits to be authentic; -- so called from itscommon use in the Latin Church.

A genus of aquatic plants named in honor of Queen Victoria. TheVictoria regia is a native of Guiana and Brazil. Its large, spreadingleaves are often over five feet in diameter, and have a rim fromthree to five inches high; its immense rose-white flowers sometimesattain a diameter of nearly two feet.
To form or work, as by inlaying, with irregular lines orimpressions resembling the tracks of worms, or appearing as if formedby the motion of worms.
Destitute of verdure.
Of or pertaining to the smallpox; having pits, or sunkenimpressions, like those of the smallpox; variolar; variolic.
See Ferrule. [Obs.]
A clock whose decorative case has the general form of a vase,esp. one in which there is no ordinary dial, but in which a part of avase revolves while a single stationary indicator serves as a hand.
To become young again. [Obs.]
In a lively manner. [Obs.]If I see a thing vively represented on the stage. B. Jonson.
An oxysulphide of lead occurring in implanted sphericalglobules of a yellowish or brownish color; -- called also voltzine.
The arrangement of the leaves within the leaf bud, as regardstheir folding, coiling, rolling, etc.; prefoliation.
To eject the contents of the stomach by the mouth; to puke; tospew.
Minutely verrucose; as, a verruculose leaf or stalk.
The quality or state of being vaporable.
Having a brilliantly polished surface, as some leaves.
The act, art, or practice, of versifying, or making verses; theconstruction of poetry; metrical composition.
A valerate.
The act, art, or practice of vaccinating, or inoculating withthe cowpox, in order to prevent or mitigate an attack of smallpox.Cf. Inoculation.
A caustic application made up of equal parts of caustic potashand quicklime; -- called also Vienna caustic.
Or or pertaining to hunting; venatic. [R.]
Any one of numerous species of American singing birds belongingto Vireo and allied genera of the family Vireonidæ. In many of thespecies the back is greenish, or olive-colored. Called also greenlet.
Food; victuals. [Obs.] Piers Plowman. Chaucer.
The quality or state of being versatile; versatileness.
A hydrous phosphate of iron of a blue to green color, growingdarker on exposure. It occurs in monoclinic crystals, also fibrous,massive, and earthy.
A circular tread; a gait by which a horse going sideways rounda center makes two concentric tracks.
Speaking truth; truthful. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being vulnerable; vulnerability.
Liable or subject to be visited or inspected. "All hospitalsbuilt since the Reformation are visitable by the king or lordchancellor." Ayliffe.
To assault; to injure; also, to bring by violence; to compel.[Obs.] B. Jonson.
The quality or power of turning; revolution; rotation. [R.]Locke.I hardly believe he hath from elder times unknown the verticity ofthe loadstone. Sir T. Browne.
The act of carrying, or state of being carried. [Obs.]
A medicine or substance that expels worms from animal bodies;an anthelmintic.
Of or pertaining to a vallation; used for a vallation; as,vallatory reads. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.

Greedy in eating; very hungry; eager to devour or swallow;ravenous; gluttonous; edacious; rapacious; as, a voracious man orappetite; a voracious gulf or whirlpool. Dampier.-- Vo*ra"cious*ly, adv.-- Vo*ra"cious*ness, n.
Abusive; scurrilous; defamatory; vile. [Obs.] "Viled speeches."Hayward.
Twentieth; divided into, or consisting of, twenties or twentyparts. Tylor.
One of the transparent lenslike cells in the ocelli of certainarthropods.
A system of philosophy among the Hindoos, founded on scatteredtexts of the Vedas, and thence termed the "Anta," or end orsubstance. Balfour (Cyc. of India.)
The quality or state of being vibratile; disposition tovibration or oscillation. Rush.
The spirit or conduct of the Vandals; ferocious cruelty;hostility to the arts and literature, or willful destruction ordefacement of their monuments.

Daring; bold; hardy; fearless; venturesome; adveturous; as, aventurous soldier. Spenser.This said, he paused not, but with venturous arm He plucked, hetasted. Milton.-- Ven"tur*ous*ly, adv.-- Ven"tur*ous*ness, n.
The calcined ashes of any coarse seaweed used for themanufacture of soda and iodine; also, the seaweed itself; fucus;wrack.
A discourse or treatise on worms; that part of zoölogy whichtreats of worms; helminthology. [R.]
To avenge; to punish; to revenge. [Obs.] See Avenge, andRevenge. Chaucer. "To venge me, as I may." Shak.
In vestiture. [R.]
A West Indian duck, sometimes domesticated.
Any species of vermetus.
Volcanism.
Universal. [Obs. or Colloq.] Shak.
Given to vaunting or boasting; vainly ostentatious; boastful;vainglorious.
Verisimilitude. [Obs.]The verisimility or probable truth. Sir T. Browne.
A cavity into which, in certain bryozoans, the esophagus andanus open.
A base, C15H27N, produced together with valeridine, which itresembles.
Any one of numerous species of rapacious birds belonging toVultur, Cathartes, Catharista, and various other genera of the familyVulturidæ.

A limited reciprocating motion of a particle of an elastic bodyor medium in alternately opposite directions from its position ofequilibrium, when that equilibrium has been disturbed, as when astretched cord or other body produces musical notes, or particles ofair transmit sounds to the ear. The path of the particle may be in astraight line, in a circular arc, or in any curve whatever.
Having the inner part cut away, or left vacant, a narrow borderbeing left at the sides, the tincture of the field being seen in thevacant space; -- said of a charge.

Of infirm health; seeking to recover health; sickly; weakly;infirm.My feeble health and valetudinarian stomach. Coleridge.The virtue which the world wants is a healthful virtue, not avaletudinarian virtue. Macaulay.
The color green, represented in a drawing or engraving byparallel lines sloping downward toward the right.
A votaress. Dryden.
An inlet, bay, or creek; -- so called in the Orkney andShetland Islands. Jamieson.
A yellowish amorphous alkaloid extracted from the rootstock ofVeratrum album.
The state of being vibrant; resonance.
A kind of velvet having cotton back.
Of or pertaining to a vertebræ, or the vertebral column;spinal; rachidian.
One who has charge of cattle, horses, etc.; a herdsman.[Southwestern U. S.]
Straight; rectilinear. [R.]
Green; not withered. [R.] Sir T. Browne.

The quality or state of being verisimilar; the appearance oftruth; probability; likelihood.Verisimilitude and opinion are an easy purchase; but true knowledgeis dear and difficult. Glanvill.All that gives verisimilitude to a narrative. Sir. W. Scott.
A decorative cabinet, of a form originating in Spain, the bodybeing rectangular and supported on legs or an ornamental frameworkand the front opening downwards on hinges to serve as a writing desk.
Quartz occurring as gangue in a vein.
Attentive to discover and avoid danger, or to provide forsafety; wakeful; watchful; circumspect; wary. "Be sober, bevigilant." 1 Pet. v. 8.Sirs, take your places, and be vigilant. Shak.
Avengement; penal retribution; vengeance. [Obs.] Spenser.

The compass of the court of Marshalsea and the Palace court,within which the lord steward and the marshal of the king's householdhad special jurisdiction; -- so called from the verge, or staff,which the marshal bore.
Having the power of seeing visions; inspired; also, seen invisions. [R.] Shelley.
A bout, or turn, as at fencing; a thrust; a hit; a veney.[Obs.] Fuller.
Word for word; in the same words; verbally; as, to tell a storyverbatim as another has related it. Verbatim et literatim Etym:[LL.], word for word, and letter for letter.
Same as Versemonger. Prior.

A stage entertainment of successive separate performances,usually songs, dances, acrobatic feats, dramatic sketches,exhibitions of trained animals, or any specialties. Often looselycalled vaudeville show.
Pertaining both to the vulva and the uterus.

A member of the most numerous of the native races of thePhilippines, occupying the Visayan Islands and the northern coastMindanao; also, their language. The Visayans possessed a nativeculture and alphabet.
The Bureau Veritas. See under Bureau.
A believer in the theory of vitalism; -- opposed to physicist.
The quality or state of being voluntary; spontaneousness;specifically, the quality or state of being free in the exercise ofone's will.
A bladderlike vessel; a membranous cavity; a cyst; a cell.Specifically: --(a) (Bot.)
The quality or state of being a vagrant; a wandering without asettled home; an unsettled condition; vagabondism.Threatened away into banishment and vagrancy. Barrow.
A form of voltaic, or galvanic, battery suitable for useelectrotyping. G. Francis.
That may be vitrified; vitrifiable.
To make vulgar, or common.Exhortation vulgarized by low wit. V. Knox.
Of or pertaining to the Vespertiliones.
The act or state of becoming green through the formation ofchlorophyll.
To alter; to make different; to vary.
The first point after deuce.
A whip scorpion, esp. a large Mexican species (Thelyphonusgiganteus) popularly supposed to be very venomous; -- from the odorthat it emits when alarmed.
Marked with veins; veined; veiny.The excellent old gentleman's nails are long and leaden, and hishands lean and veinous. Dickens.
A genus of polypetalous herbaceous plants, including all kindsof violets.
Of or pertaining to veins; venous; as, venal blood. [R.]
Same as Vulpic.
Crying like a child. [Obs.]
In a vicarious manner.
To subject to, or cause to undergo, volcanic heat, and to beaffected by its action.
Of or pertaining to cows; pertaining to, derived from, orcaused by, vaccinia; as, vaccine virus; the vaccine disease.-- n.
Vast; immense. [R.]I can call spirits from the vasty deep. Shak.
Vile. [Obs.] "That vild race." Spenser.-- Vild"ly, adv. [Obs.] Spenser.
Having the form of a straight rod; wand-shaped; straight andslender.

A vein. Vena cava; pl. Venæ cavæ. Etym: [L., literally, hollowvein.] (Anat.) Any one of the great systemic veins connected directlywith the heart.-- Vena contracta. Etym: [L., literally, contractedvein.] (Hydraulics) The contracted portion of a liquid jet at andnear the orifice from which it issues.-- Vena portæ; pl. VenÆ portæ. Etym: [L., literally, vein of theentrance.] (Anat.) The portal vein of the liver. See under Portal.
Blossoming in the evening.
A genus of ericaceous shrubs including the various kinds ofblueberries and the true cranberries.
Of a pertaining to the bladder and the prostrate gland.
The hunting spiders, which run after, or leap upon, their prey.
Extremely; excessively. [Obs.] "He loves that vengeancely."Beau. & Fl.
A clear, viscous, tasteless substance extracted from themucilaginous sap of the mistletoe (Viscum album), holly, etc., andconstituting an essential ingredient of birdlime.
See Visor.
An indefinite expanse. [R.]The gray vague of unsympathizing sea. Lowell.
Carrying or bearing sails. [Obs.] "Veliferous chariots."Evelyn.
In a virulent manner.
Devouring worms; feeding on worms; as, vermivorous birds.
To endue with life; to make to be living; to quicken; toanimate.Sitting on eggs doth vivify, not nourish. Bacon.
Existing in a vaporous form or state; as, steam is a vaporiformsubstance.
Adapted to, or used in, vibratory motion; having the power ofvibrating; vibratory; as, the vibratile organs of insects.
A binding. [Obs.]
To value lightly; to depreciate; to slight; to despise.To vilipend the art of portrait painting. Longfellow.
Having the place of articulation on the soft palate; guttural;as, the velar consonants, such as k and hard q.
Power; force; energy; spirit; activity; vigor. [Colloq.]
See Farthingale. [Spelled also verdingall.] [Obs.]
Volumetric.-- Vol`u*met"ric*al*ly, adv.
Having the nerves, or veins, placed in apparent disorder.
Furnished with vowels. [Written also vowelled.] Dryden.
Benne (Sesamum orientale); also, its seeds; -- so called in theWest Indies.
In electrotypy, the act or art of copying, in metals depositedby electrolytic action, a form or pattern which is made the negativeelectrode. [R.]
An instrument for measuring the voltaic electricity passingthrough it, by its effect in decomposing water or some other chemicalcompound acting as an electrolyte.

The act, art, or practice of speaking in such a manner that thevoice appears to come, not from the person speaking, but from someother source, as from the opposite side of the room, from the cellar,etc.
Contraction for Vingt et un.

Rate of motion; the relation of motion to time, measured by thenumber of units of space passed over by a moving body or point in aunit of time, usually the number of feet passed over in a second. Seethe Note under Speed. Angular velocity. See under Angular.-- Initial velocity, the velocity of a moving body at starting;especially, the velocity of a projectile as it leaves the mouth of afirearm from which it is discharged.-- Relative velocity, the velocity with which a body approaches orrecedes from another body, whether both are moving or only one.-- Uniform velocity, velocity in which the same number of units ofspace are described in each successive unit of time.-- Variable velocity, velocity in which the space described variesfrom instant, either increasing or decreasing; -- in the former casecalled accelerated velocity, in the latter, retarded velocity; theacceleration or retardation itself being also either uniform orvariable.-- Virtual velocity. See under Virtual.
Of or, pertaining to hunting.
The arrangement or system of veins, as in the wing of aninsect, or in the leaves of a plant. See Illust. in Appendix.
A sauce, made of vinegar, oil, and other ingredients, -- usedesp. for cold meats.

The face, countenance, or look of a person or an animal; --chiefly applied to the human face. Chaucer. "A visage of demand."Shak.His visage was so marred more than any man. Isa. lii. 14.Love and beauty still that visage grace. Waller.
To bring back a metal to the metallic form, as from an oxide orsolution; to reduce. [Obs.]
A vaginula.

A large and handsome American butterfly (Basilarchia, orLimenitis, archippus). Its wings are orange-red, with black linesalong the nervures and a row of white spots along the outer margins.The larvæ feed on willow, poplar, and apple trees.
Any tropical humming bird of the genus Petasophora, havingviolet or purplish ear tufts.
The theories or practice of Voltaire. J. Morley.
Inflammation of the vagina, or the genital canal, usually ofits mucous living membrane.

The front of an army; the first line or leading column; also,the front line or foremost division of a fleet, either in sailing orin battle.Standards and gonfalons, twixt van and rear, Stream in the air.Milton.
A union, association, or society; -- used in names of Germanorganizations.
The spasmodic ejection of matter from the stomach through themouth.
Of or pertaining to wine; having the qualities of wine; as, avinous taste.
Quality or state of being volcanic; volcanic power.
One who vamps; one who pieces an old thing with something new;a cobbler.

That form of electricity which is developed by the chemicalaction between metals and different liquids; voltaic electricity;also, the science which treats of this form of electricity; -- calledalso galvanism, from Galvani, on account of his experiments showingthe remarkable influence of this agent on animals.
Conveying or producing vapor.

Intermission of judicial proceedings; the space of time betweenthe end of one term and the beginning of the next; nonterm; recess."With lawyers in the vacation." Shak.(b) The intermission of the regular studies and exercises of aneducational institution between terms; holidays; as, the springvacation.(c) The time when an office is vacant; esp. (Eccl.), the time when asee, or other spiritual dignity, is vacant.
A victress. [Obs.] Spenser.

a. & vb. n. from Visit. Visiting ant. (Zoöl.) See Driver ant,under Driver.-- Visiting book, a book in which a record of visits received, made,and to be made, is kept. Thackeray.-- Visiting card. See under Card.
A blood feud; private revenge for the murder of a kinsman.
Formed with different shapes; having various forms; variform.
The quality or state of being vast.
Represented as flying, or having the wings spread; as, an eaglevolant. Volant piece (Anc. Armor), an adjustable piece of armor, forguarding the throat, etc., in a joust.
A laying waste; waste; depopulation; devastation. [Obs.] Bp.Hall.
Beginning to be green; slightly green; greenish.
A line, within a rotating fluid, whose tangent at every pointis the instantaneous axis of rotation as that point of the fluid.
Vagabondage.
One who uses, or sustains the use of, the veto.
A vender; a seller; the correlative of vendee.
The turning factor of a quaternion.
Any one of numerous species of marine Bryozoa belonging toVesicularia and allied genera. They have delicate tubular cellsattached in clusters to slender flexible stems.
Divided by pallets, or pales; paly. W. Berry.
The act or process of converting into vapor, or of passing offin vapor; evaporation. [R.]
An arrow, having a rotary motion, formerly used with thecrossbow. Cf. Vireton. Gower.

A rare element of the nitrogen-phosphorus group, foundcombined, in vanadates, in certain minerals, and reduced as aninfusible, grayish-white metallic powder. It is intermediate betweenthe metals and the non-metals, having both basic and acid properties.Sumbol V (or Vd, rarely). Atomic weight 51.2.
Of or pertaining to worms; wormy.
Having delegated power, as a vicar; vicarious. Barrow.
Of or pertaining to a viceroy or viceroyalty. Macaulay.

Having relation to growth or nutrition; partaking of simplegrowth and enlargement of the systems of nutrition, apart from thesensorial or distinctively animal functions; vegetal.-- Veg"e*ta*tive*ly, adv.-- Veg"e*ta*tive*ness, n.
Like a volcano.
A wand. See Verge. [Obs.]
Tennessee; -- a nickname.
The act or operation of opening a vein for letting blood;bloodletting; phlebotomy.
To discharge with, or as with, a volley.
Of or pertaining to a farm or a village; rural. "Tame villaticfowl." Milton.
To play the vagabond; to wander about in idleness.
In a vexing manner; so as to vex, tease, or irritate. Tatler.
The body of vassals. [R.]
See Wastel. [Obs.] Fuller.
Inflammation of a vesicle.
A directed quantity, as a straight line, a force, or avelocity. Vectors are said to be equal when their directions are thesame their magnitudes equal. Cf. Scalar.
Quality or state of being viridescent.
Of or pertaining to Verona, in Italy.-- n. sing. & pl.
A Veronica. See Veronica, 1. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.A vernicle had he sowed upon his cap. Chaucer.
Covered by, or as by, a veil; hidden. "Words used to convey aveiled meaning." Earle.
The quality or state of being vascular.

One who wanders from place to place, having no fixed dwelling,or not abiding in it, and usually without the means of honestlivelihood; a vagrant; a tramp; hence, a worthless person; a rascal.A fugitive and a vagabond shalt thou be. Gen. iv. 12.

Any one of numerous species of ciliated Infusoria belonging toVorticella and many other genera of the family Vorticellidæ. Theyhave a more or less bell-shaped body with a circle of vibrating ciliaaround the oral disk. Most of the species have slender, contractilestems, either simple or branched.
See Villous.

A cavity, or one of the cavities, of an organ, as of the larynxor the brain; specifically, the posterior chamber, or one of the twoposterior chambers, of the heart, which receives the blood from theauricle and forces it out from the heart. See Heart.
Subject to vicissitudes. Donne.
One who makes a vow. Bale.
The region immediately surrounding a disk moving flatwisethrough air; -- so called because the air has a cyclic motion as invortex ring.
Of or pertaining to the bladder and the vagina.
The dealfish. [Written also vaagmær, and vaagmar.]
A region or tract of land; esp., the open field; grass country.[South Africa]
A light puff paste, with a raised border, filled, after baking,usually with a ragout of fowl, game, or fish.
One who cultivates, prunes, or cares for, grapevines; a laborerin a vineyard.The sons of the shall be your plowmen and your vinedressers. Isa.lxi. 5.
The process of vesicating, or of raising blisters.
One of the movable, slender, spinelike organs or parts withwhich certain bryozoans are furnished. They are regarded as speciallymodified zooids, of nearly the same nature as Avicularia.
Food; diet.
A condition of the uterus in which its axis is deflected fromits normal position without being bent upon itself. See Anteversion,and Retroversion.
A process by which ores are washed on a shovel, or in a vanner.
Liable to, or deserving, vituperation, or severe censure.
See Vitiate. [R.]
See Vauntmure. [Obs.]
See Vifda.
A wand or staff of authority or justice. [Obs.]His hand a vare of justice did uphold. Dryden.
An elevation, or crest, in the wall of the urethra where theseminal ducts enter it.

Pertaining to, or containing, vanadium; specifically,designating those compounds in which vanadium has a lower valence ascontrasted with the vanadic compounds; as, vanadious acid. [Sometimeswritten also vanadous.]

Any plant or flower of the genus Viola, of many species. Theviolets are generally low, herbaceous plants, and the flowers of manyof the species are blue, while others are white or yellow, or ofseveral colors, as the pansy (Viola tricolor).
Capable of being converted into a vitriol.

The porch or entrance into a house; a hall or antechamber nextthe entrance; a lobby; a porch; a hall. Vestibule of the ear. (Anat.)See under Ear.-- Vestibule of the vulva (Anat.), a triangular space between thenymphæ, in which the orifice of the urethra is situated.-- Vestibule train (Railroads), a train of passenger cars having thespace between the end doors of adjacent cars inclosed, so as to admitof leaving the doors open to provide for intercommunication betweenall the cars.
Victress. C. Bronté.
See Society verses, under Society.
The quality or state of being venial; venialness. Jer. Taylor.
Gold powder for covering varnished surfaces.
The quality or state of being vendible, or salable.
See Vermeil. [Obs.] Spenser.

A unit of electric measurement equal to the product of a voltand an ampere. For direct current it is a measure of power and is thesame as a watt; for alternating current it is a measure of apparentpower.
The quality or state of being verecund; modesty. [Obs.]
Developed in manhood; hence, able to beget; marriageable.[Obs.]Being not of ripe years, not viripotent. Holinshed.
Venial; pardonable. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.-- Ve"ni*a*bly, adv. [Obs.] Sir T. Browne.
Of or pertaining to vaccinia or vaccination.
A large wig that shades the face. [Obs.]
One who vaunts; a boaster.
Having varvels, or rings. [Written also varvelled, andvervelled.]
See Volery. [Obs.]
A trim, pointed beard, such as those often seen in pictures byVandyke.
In a verminous manner.
